In January 2009, the City of [[Albert Lea, Minnesota]] began the [[AARP]]/[[Blue Zones]] Vitality Project. Sponsored by United Health Foundation and led by [[Dan Buettner]], the author of ''The Blue Zone: Lessons for Living Longer From the People Who've Lived the Longest'', the Vitality Project's goal was to add 10,000 years to the lives of Albert Lea residents by encouraging them to make small changes in their daily lives.<ref> {{Citation | last = Tomczyk | first = Amy | title = About the Vitality Project | url=http://www.bluezones.com/vitality-project-about | accessdate = 23 October 2009 }}</ref><ref> {{Citation | title = All About the Project: How AARP and Blue Zones created America's healthiest hometown | url=http://www.aarpmagazine.org/health/vitality_national/about.html | accessdate = 23 October 2009 }}</ref><ref> {{Citation | last = Stultz | first = Sarah | title = Vitality Project leader: 'You've pulled it off' | newspaper = The Albert Lea Tribune | location = Albert Lea, Minnesota | date = 14 October 2009 | url =http://www.albertleatribune.com/news/2009/oct/14/vitality-project-leader-youve-pulled-it/ | accessdate = <!-----23 October 2009----->}} </ref>
==Vitality Project Initiatives== The [[AARP]]/[[Blue Zones]] Vitality Project is divided into several different initiatives.<ref> {{Citation | last = Tribune Staff | title = Vitality Project participants add an average of 3 years of life expectancy | newspaper = The Albert Lea Tribune | location = Albert Lea, Minnesota | date = 13 October 2009 | url =http://www.albertleatribune.com/news/2009/oct/13/albert-lea-vitality-project-participants-add-3-yea/ | accessdate = <!----- 23 October 2009 ----->}}</ref> The categories for the initiatives were habitat, social networking, [[community]], and purpose. Some initiatives proved to be specific to one category while others spanned several categories.<ref> {{Citation | title = Resources | url=http://www.aarpmagazine.org/health/vitality_project/resources.html | accessdate = 23 October 2009 }} </ref>
* '''Walking Moai Program:''' Over 500 participants joined approximately 70 "walking moais," which were groups of 4-10 walkers who agreed to meet once a week and walk to a set destination and back. They collectively walked over 75 million steps and approximately 32,000 miles. In addition, Walking Moai participants did over 2,200 hours of volunteer work.<ref> {{Citation | title = Recorded Steps: Walking Moai | url=http://moai.albertleajournal.com | accessdate = 23 October 2009 }}</ref> Both steps and volunteer hours were compiled for each group as part of an overall Walking Moai competition.<ref> {{Citation | last = Erickson | first = Jeshua | title = Walking Moai competition heats up | newspaper = The Albert Lea Tribune | location = Albert Lea, Minnesota | date = 26 June 2009 | url = http://www.albertleatribune.com/weblogs/jeshua-erickson/2009/jun/26/walking-moai-competition-heats/ | accessdate = <!----- 27 October 2009 ----->}}</ref>
* '''Walking School Bus:''' The Walking School Bus Program found parents and volunteers to walk with groups of children to their respective elementary schools. A [[walking bus]] is said to encourage children to walk more, help build social networks, and assist in keeping kids safe on their way to school.<ref name=usatoday> {{Citation | last = Marcus | first = Mary Brophy | title = Town sets off on healthy path practicing 4 keys to longevity | newspaper = USA Today | location = Albert Lea, Minnesota | date = 15 June 2009 | url =https://www.usatoday.com/news/health/2009-06-14-longevity_N.htm | accessdate = <!----- 23 October 2009 ----->}} </ref>
* '''Vitality Compass:''' The Vitality Compass is an online tool which is now available nationwide. It asks participants questions about their eating habits, sleeping habits, levels of stress, and amount of daily activity. At the end of the online survey, participants are given an age which is their approximate life expectancy. For the purposes of determining the efficacy of certain aspects of the Vitality Project participants were asked to take the Vitality Compass twice; once at the beginning of the program and again at the end. The average [[life expectancy]] for those who took the Vitality Compass at the beginning and at the end of the program increased by three years.<ref> {{Citation | last = Stultz | first = Sarah | title = 1 week remains to retake Vitality Compass | newspaper = The Albert Lea Tribune | location = Albert Lea, Minnesota | date = 6 October 2009 | url = http://www.albertleatribune.com/news/2009/oct/06/1-week-remains-retake-vitality-compass/ | accessdate = <!----- 23 October 2009 ----->}} </ref>
* '''Volunteering:''' Vitality Project organizers encouraged participants to volunteer in their community.<ref> {{Citation | last = Tribune Staff | title = Vitality Living series: Kenyan foods, American life | newspaper = The Albert Lea Tribune | location = Albert Lea, Minnesota | date = 22 October 2009 | url = http://www.albertleatribune.com/news/2009/oct/22/vitality-living-series-kenyan-foods-american-life/ | accessdate = <!----- 23 October 2009 ----->}} </ref>
* '''Employers:''' Employers were encouraged to make their work environments more amenable to practices leading to good health. For example, some employers added healthy alternatives to vending machines.<ref> {{Citation | last = Tribune Staff | title = Employers to be recognized for participation in Vitality Project pledge | newspaper = The Albert Lea Tribune | location = Albert Lea, Minnesota | date = 3 October 2009 | url = http://www.albertleatribune.com/news/2009/oct/22/vitality-living-series-kenyan-foods-american-life/ | accessdate = <!----- 23 October 2009 ----->}} </ref>
* '''Grocery Stores:''' Vitality Project organizers encouraged grocery stores to feature those foods which are thought to engender better health and increased life expectancy.<ref name=usatoday /><ref> {{Citation | last = Stultz | first = Sarah | title = Local diet, exercise workers welcome Blue Zones advice | newspaper = The Albert Lea Tribune | location = Albert Lea, Minnesota | date = 9 September 2009 | url = http://www.albertleatribune.com/news/2009/sep/26/local-diet-exercise-workers-welcome-blue-zones-adv/ | accessdate = <!----- 23 October 2009 ----->}} </ref>
* '''Neighborhood Picnics:''' To encourage [[community]] building and social networking, several neighborhood picnics were held and all people in a given neighborhood were invited to attend.<ref> {{Citation | last = Harvey | first = Ken | title = A Minnesota Blue Zone? It's closer than before | newspaper = MinnPost.com | location = Albert Lea, Minnesota | date = 26 August 2009 | url = http://www.minnpost.com/stories/2009/08/26/11118/a_minnesota_blue_zone_its_closer_than_before | accessdate = <!----- 23 October 2009 ----->}} </ref>
* '''Community Gardens:''' The City of Albert Lea in cooperation with the Vitality Project made space available for citizens of Albert Lea to plant vegetables and flowers.<ref> {{Citation | last = Williams | first = Chris and Patrick Condon | title = Minn. city's get-healthy effort called a success | newspaper = Associated Press | location = Albert Lea, Minnesota | date = 14 October 2009 | url = http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_TOWNS_HEALTHY_MAKEOVER?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&CTIME=2009-10-14-13-58-44 | accessdate = <!----- 26 October 2009 ----->}} </ref>
* '''Purpose Workshops:''' Workshops addressing the importance of finding one's sense of purpose were provided to Albert Leans for free.<ref> {{Citation | last = Stultz | first = Sarah | title = Final chance for attending a free purpose workshop | newspaper = The Albert Lea Tribune | location = Albert Lea, Minnesota | date = 3 October 2009 | url = http://www.albertleatribune.com/news/2009/oct/03/final-chance-attending-free/ | accessdate = <!----- 23 October 2009 ----->}} </ref> The workshops were led by Richard Leider, a nationally known executive coach who is also founder and chairman of ''The Inventure Group''<ref> {{Citation | last = Stultz | first = Sarah | title = Expert: Purpose matters | newspaper = The Albert Lea Tribune | location = Albert Lea, Minnesota | date = 21 May 2009 | url = http://www.albertleatribune.com/news/2009/may/21/expert-purpose-matters/ | accessdate = <!----- 27 October 2009 ----->}}</ref>
==Walkability== Early in the Vitality Project, organizers invited [http://www.walklive.org/?page_id=17 Dan Burden], a nationally recognized expert in the area of "walkability," to come speak to community leaders and do a "walkability audit."<ref> {{Citation | title = Walkability Audit | url = http://www.cityofalbertlea.org/?page_id=3994 | accessdate = 26 October 2009}} </ref> In this audit, Burden toured Albert Lea on foot and pointed out ways that the city could make Albert Lea more walkable.<ref>{{Citation | last = Engstrom | first = Tim | title = Walkable audit of Albert Lea offers Bridge Avenue ideas | newspaper = The Albert Lea Tribune | location = Albert Lea, Minnesota | date = 16 January 2009 | url = http://www.albertleatribune.com/news/2009/jan/16/walkable-audit-albert-lea-offers-bridge-avenue-ide/ | accessdate = <!----- 26 October 2009 ----->}}</ref> Since then the city has added sidewalk which connects several portions of a well traveled path around Fountain Lake.<ref> {{Citation | last = Stultz | first = Sarah | title = City celebrates sidewalks around lake | newspaper = The Albert Lea Tribune | location = Albert Lea, Minnesota | date = 7 October 2009 | url = http://www.albertleatribune.com/news/2009/oct/07/city-leaders-celebrate-completion-sidewalks-around/ | accessdate = <!----- 23 October 2009 ----->}}</ref>
==Sustainability== The City of [[Albert Lea, Minnesota]] put together a sustainability committee which focuses on keeping practices put in place by Vitality Project organizers and volunteers. The long-term goal is that the Albert Lea will have a Vitality Center where leaders of other cities, organizations, and individuals can come to learn about how making small changes in lifestyle as a community can help to improve health and life expectancy.<ref> {{Citation | title = Vitality Project 2010 | url = http://www.cityofalbertlea.org/?page_id=4079 | accessdate = <!----- 26 October 2009 ----->}} </ref>
On October 26, 2009, the Albert Lea City Council voted to designate the lower level of the Jacobson Apartment Building on Broadway Avenue in downtown Albert Lea as the Vitality Center. The space will be refurbished and updated to accommodate the Vitality Center. The city's goal is that the Vitality Center be opened in the first part of 2010.<ref> {{Citation | last = Stultz | first = Sarah | title = Council makes Vitality Center plans official | newspaper = The Albert Lea Tribune | location = Albert Lea, Minnesota | date = 26 October 2009 | url = http://www.albertleatribune.com/news/2009/oct/26/council-makes-vitality-center-plans-official/ | accessdate = <!----- 26 October 2009 ----->}} </ref>
==Media coverage== The Vitality Project was featured in a variety of news outlets and publications. Among them are Good Morning America,<ref> {{Citation | last = Ferran | first = Lee | title = Vitality Project: Did It Make a Town Healthier? | newspaper = ABC News | location = Albert Lea, Minnesota | date = 14 October 2009 | url = http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/VitalityProject/vitality-project-make-town-healthier/story?id=8818625 | accessdate = <!----- 26 October 2009 ----->}} </ref> USA Today,<ref name=usatoday /> Minneapolis Star Tribune,<ref> {{Citation | last = Wolfe | first = Warren | title = Albert Lea healthy-living project ends - but surveys remain | newspaper = Minneapolis Star Tribune | location = Albert Lea, Minnesota | date = 13 October 2009 | url = http://www.startribune.com/local/64177622.html?elr=KArks8c7PaP3E77K_3c::D3aDhUoaEaD_ec7PaP3iUiacyKU7DYaGEP7vDEh7P:DiUs | accessdate = <!----- 26 October 2009 ----->}} </ref> Minnesota Public Radio.<ref> {{Citation | last = Baier | first = Elizabeth | title = In Albert Lea, lifestyle changes lead to healthier lives | newspaper = MPR News | location = Albert Lea, Minnesota | date = 13 October 2009 | url = http://minnesota.publicradio.org/display/web/2009/10/13/albert-lea-healthy-living/ | accessdate = <!----- 26 October 2009 ----->}} </ref> ==See also== *[[Blue Zone]] *[[Beach Cities Health District]] *[[Longevity]]
==External links== * [http://www.bluezones.com/ Blue Zones] * [http://www.bluezones.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=26&Itemid=6 The Vitality Compass] * [http://www.aarpmagazine.org/health/vitality_national/ Vitality Project Page at AARP] * [http://www.richardleider.com/ Richard Leider]

{{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{otheruses}} [[File:Blue and white faience albarello with designs derived from Kufic script Toscane 2nd half 15th century.jpg|thumb|[[Blue-and-white]] [[faience]] albarello with [[Pseudo-Kufic]] designs, [[Tuscany]], 2nd half of 15th century.]] An '''albarello''' (plural: ''albarelli'') is a type of [[maiolica]] earthenware jar, originally a [[medicinal jar]] designed to hold [[apothecary|apothecaries']] ointments and dry drugs. The development of this type of pharmacy jar had its roots in the Middle East during the time of the Islamic conquests.
==History== The etymology of the word is not clear. Some scholars consider the Latin word ''"albaris"'' with the meaning of "whitish"<ref>[[Max Pfister]], ''[[Lessico etimologico italiano]]'', Reichert, Wiesbaden 1979</ref> while others criticize this interpretation as such recipients were originally manufactured in wood.<ref>Enrico Bianchi, ''Lingua Nostra I'', 1939 (pag. 77)</ref><ref>Angelico Prati, ''Vocabolario etimologico italiano'', Garzanti, 1951</ref> Parchment was white, or bleached white, so that the contents of the jar could be written upon it. The parchment would overlap the upper half of the jar in order to be affixed with a cord and properly seal the contents.
Brought to Italy by [[Hispano-Moresque]] traders, the earliest Italian examples were produced in Florence in the 15th century. ''Albarelli'' were made in [[Italy]] from the first half of the 15th century through to the late 18th century and beyond. Based on Persian designs said to emulate bamboo (the traditional manufacturing material), the jars are usually cylindrical with a slightly concave waist. Variations in size and style can be seen from region to region, ranging from 10 cm to 40 cm in height. Such jars served both functional and decorative purposes in traditional apothecaries and [[pharmacies]], and represented status and wealth. The jars were generally sealed with a piece of [[parchment]] or [[leather]] tied with a piece of cord.
The maiolica potter's preoccupation with ornamentation and design is nowhere more in evidence than on albarelli during the [[Renaissance]]. Common design themes include floral motifs against a white background, to more elaborate designs such as portraits of a [[cherub]] or [[priest]], and can include a label describing the contents of the jar. Specific styles of decoration are now associated with various Italian locations, including [[Florence]], [[Venice]], [[Gerace]] and [[Palermo]] in [[Sicily]].
==Literature== * Henry Wallis: ''The Albarello'', London 1904

[[File:Medical Instruments O&G Ayre's spatula and Slide holding bottle.jpg|thumb|An Ayre spatula (bottom) with a slide holding bottle]] Ayre spatula is a device used to collect [[Pap smear]]. It is a wooden spatula with U shaped openings on one side and a flat surface on another.<ref>{{cite web|title=Collecting and processing cellular samples from the cervix|url=http://www.eurocytology.eu/en/course/1119|website=Eurocytology|publisher=Leonardo Davinci project|accessdate=19 November 2016}}</ref> The broad end is for vaginal sample collection and the narrow end is for cervical sample collection. It is rotated 360 degrees in the vagina to obtain the cells to be sent for Pap smear examination. Recent studies have shown that long-tipped spatulas ([[Aylesbury device]]) or a [[cytobrush]] along with an extended-tip spatula are better than Ayre spatula in collecting [[endocervix|endocervical cells]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Vatanaspat|first1=V|title=Collection Devices for Obtaining cervical cytology samples|url=http://apps.who.int/rhl/gynaecology/cancer/vvcom/en/|website=The WHO reproductive health library|publisher=World Health Organization|accessdate=19 November 2016}}</ref> However, Ayre spatula continues to be used for cervical sample collection in less-income countries. Ayre spatula is introduced into the cervix after visualizing the os using a [[Speculum (medical)|speculum]]. The [[cytology]] specimens are obtained by rotating the spatula firmly over the [[ectocervix]] and quickly transferring the cells to a slide or jar. ==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox Politician (general) | name= Balwant Singh Rakkha | image= | image_width= | title= Member of House of Representatives (Fiji)
Ba Indian Communal Constituency | term_start= 1987 | term_end= 1987 | predecessor= Navin Patel | successor= Constitution abrogated | title2= | term_start2= | term_end2= | predecessor2= | successor2= | title3= | term_start3= | term_end3= | predecessor3= | successor3= | title4= | term_start4= | term_end4= | predecessor4= | successor4= | birth_date= 1941 | birth_place= Tavua, Fiji | death_date= | death_place= | party= National Federation Party | residence= Ba Fiji | spouse= | profession= Medical Doctor | religion= Sikh | footnotes= }} '''Balwant Singh Rakkha''' (born 1941) was a [[Indians in Fiji|Fiji Indian]] medical [[Physician|doctor]] and a member of the [[House of Representatives of Fiji|House of Representatives]] of [[Fiji]] representing the [[National Federation Party]] (NFP), but he is best known for his strong support for the former leader of the NFP, [[Sidiq Koya]] and the split caused within the NFP when he was rewarded by Koya for his loyalty by being given a seat in a constituency where he was a virtual unknown. Rakkha was born in [[Tavua, Fiji|Tavua]] and went to [[India]] to study medicine. He returned to Fiji after fourteen years and established a practice in [[Ba District, Fiji|Ba]]. He joined the NFP in 1975 and was the President of the Ba branch from 1977. When the [[Lautoka]] Indian [[Communal constituencies|Communal seat]] became vacant in April 1984 following the resignation of the former leader of the NFP, [[Jai Ram Reddy]], Rakkha was selected to contest the by-election for the NFP. [[Davendra Singh]], a virtually unknown small businessman, managed to persuade the [[NFP Youth Wing]], which had earlier been shunned by Koya, to support him to oppose Rakkha. Singh demanded that a local person be selected by NFP for the vacant seat but when he was ignored by the Party, he nominated himself for the election. The result was a narrow win for Singh by 2209 votes to Rakkha's 2196 votes in an election in which only 4421 of the 12,260 registered voters cast their votes. The election result triggered a series of events which led to the decline of the NFP and the rise of the [[Fiji Labour Party]] (FLP). For the [[Fijian general election, 1987|1987 general election]], the [[NFP–Labour Coalition]] chose him as a candidate for the Ba Indian Communal Constituency which he won easily,{{cite book |last=Howard |first=Michael |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Fiji: Race and politics in an island state |year=1991 |publisher= UBC Press|location=Vancouver |isbn= 0-7748-0368-1 | pages =383}} but was a member of Parliament for a month when the [[1987 Fijian coups d'état|military coup of 1987]] put a temporary halt to his political career. In 1994 he stood for the Ba East/Tavua Rural Indian Constituency and lost narrowly to his [[Fiji Labour Party]] opponent.{{cite news|title= Fiji Times '94 General Election Scoreboard|work= |publisher=[[Fiji Times]] |date= 28 February 1994}} == References == {{DEFAULTSORT:Rakkha, Balwant Singh}} [[Category:Fijian Sikhs]] [[Category:National Federation Party politicians]] [[Category:Indian members of the House of Representatives (Fiji)]] [[Category:1941 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Fijian medical doctors]] [[Category:Politicians from Tavua, Fiji]]

{{one source|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox company | name = Bank für Sozialwirtschaft AG | logo = [[File:Bank für Sozialwirtschaft 201x logo.svg|200px]] | type = | industry = Specialized commercial bank for companies, institutions and organizations from the areas of health, social services and education | foundation = 1923{{Cite web|url=https://www.sozialbank.de/ueber-uns/unsere-geschichte.html|title=Ohne Herkunft keine Zukunft: unsere Geschichte|last=|first=|date=|website=Bank für Sozialwirtschaft|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=23 May 2018}} | location = [[Cologne]] and [[Berlin]], [[Germany]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.handelsblatt.com/finanzen/banken-versicherungen/caritas-und-rotes-kreuz-waren-taufpaten-der-bank-fuer-sozialwirtschaft-wohlfahrtsverbaende-betreiben-ihr-eigenes-kreditinstitut/2402036.html|title=Wohlfahrtsverbände betreiben ihr eigenes Kreditinstitut|last=|first=|date=17 September 2004|website=Handelsblatt|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=15 June 2018}} | products = | revenue = | parent = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.sozialbank.de/}} }} The '''Bank für Sozialwirtschaft AG''' (BFS) is a specialized commercial bank for companies, institutions and organizations from the areas of health, social services (support for the elderly and disabled people, child and youth services) and education which is located in [[Cologne]] and [[Berlin]]. ==Ownership== The bank was founded in March 1923 at the urging of the Reichsarbeitsministeriums (federal ministry of labor) as financial institute of the ''Freie Wohlfahrtspflege'' (free social welfare services) and operated in the beginning under the name ''Hilfskasse gemeinnütziger Wohlfahrtseinrichtungen Deutschlands G.m.b.H.''. In 1929 it became the ''Berufsgenossenschaft für Gesundheitsdienst und Wohlfahrtspflege''. Still today [[shareholder]]s of the bank are [[umbrella organization]]s of the free social welfare and its [[Foundation (nonprofit)|foundations]]. Stockholders are the ''Deutscher Caritasverband'' and the foundation ''Kronenkreuz'' ([[Diakonisches Werk]]) with each 25,5%, ''Arbeiterwohlfahrt'' (labor welfare association) with 7,9 %, ''Paritätische Wohlfahrtsverband'' (parity welfare association) with 3,6 %, [[German Red Cross]] with 2,4 % and ''Zentralwohlfahrtsstelle der Juden'' (Jewish welfare association) with 0,7 %. The rest is free float.{{Cite web|url=https://www.sozialbank.de/ueber-uns/unternehmen/anteilseigner.html|title=Verwurzelt in der Freien Wohlfahrtspflege|last=|first=|date=|website=Bank für Sozialwirtschaft|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=23 May 2018}} ==Business mission== The BFS offers all services and products of a [[universal bank]]. However, it is a specialized commercial bank in regards to its limited range of [[customer]]s. The [[Consultant|consulting]] is focused on the traditional business and includes not only banking specific aspects but also financing terms and conditions of health and [[Social economy|social management]]. Those are especially shaped by [[social insurance]]s and social legislation. In addition, the bank offers branch specific products such as social economic [[Mezzanine capital|mezzanine fonds]], online-[[factoring (finance)|factoring]] and [[Service (economics)|services]] for donation-based organizations. Services like production site and competitor analysis for [[Nursing home care|care homes]], [[Feasibility study|feasibility studies]], collateral value assessments and valuation reports, a wide-ranging seminar program as well as publications and presentations on the latest legal and economic issues in the health and social management sector are also on offer at BFS. BFS operates in 16 locations in Germany ([[Berlin]], [[Dresden]], [[Erfurt]], [[Essen]], [[Hamburg]], [[Hanover]], [[Karlsruhe]], [[Kassel]], [[Cologne]], [[Leipzig]], [[Magdeburg]], [[Mainz]], [[Munich]], [[Nuremberg]], [[Rostock]], [[Stuttgart]]) and runs a [[Europe]]an office in [[Brussels]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.bfs-investorrelations.de/fileadmin/user_upload/Geschaeftsberichte/2017/|title=Geschäftsbericht 2017|last=|first=|date=2017|website=Bank für Sozialwirtschaft|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=23 May 2018}} == Key figures == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Index ! 2017 ! 2016{{Cite web|url=https://www.sozialbank.de/fileadmin/2015/documents/2_Ueber_uns/2.3_Investor_Relations/2.3.1_Geschaeftsberichte/Geschaeftsbericht_2016.pdf|title=Geschäftsbericht 2016|last=|first=|date=|website=Bank für Sozialwirtschaft|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=23 May 2018}} ! 2015{{Cite web|url=https://www.sozialbank.de/fileadmin/2015/documents/2_Ueber_uns/2.3_Investor_Relations/2.3.1_Geschaeftsberichte/Geschaeftsbericht_2015.pdf|title=Geschäftsbericht 2015|last=|first=|date=|website=Bank für Sozialwirtschaft|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=23 May 2018}} ! 2014{{Cite web|url=https://www.sozialbank.de/fileadmin/2015/documents/2_Ueber_uns/2.3_Investor_Relations/2.3.1_Geschaeftsberichte/Geschaeftsbericht_2014.pdf|title=Geschäftsbericht 2014|last=|first=|date=|website=Bank für Sozialwirtschaft|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=23 May 2018}} ! 2013{{Cite web|url=|title=Geschäftsbericht 2013|last=|first=|date=|website=Bank für Sozialwirtschaft|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=23 May 2018}} ! 2012 |- | style="text-align:left" | Total assets

'''Barry Austin ''' (born 1968), of [[Solihull]], [[West Midlands (county)|West Midlands]], [[England]] is a man widely reputed to be the fattest man in the [[United Kingdom]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/3080296.stm|title= 'Eating less is the real answer'|publisher= BBC|work= BBC News|date= 4 September 2003|accessdate= 13 October 2010}}</ref>
Multiple press reports claim that at his peak weight, he weighed 50 stone (around 700 lbs or 320 kg).<ref name=why>[http://observer.guardian.co.uk/uk_news/story/0,6903,1572754,00.html Why 50-stone Barry seized a chance of life] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051227182310/http://observer.guardian.co.uk/uk_news/story/0%2C6903%2C1572754%2C00.html |date=December 27, 2005 }}, [[The Observer]], September 18, 2005</ref>
Austin's appearances in the press and on television are usually related to current concerns about an alarming increase in obesity among the population. He has thus been asked to comment on news and current affairs strands such as the [[BBC]]'s [[Breakfast News]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}} Austin has also been the star of a [[Sky One]] documentary, ''Inside Britain's Fattest Man'', presented by fellow [[Solihull|Silhillian]] [[Richard Hammond]] in the manner of the [[science fiction]] film ''[[Fantastic Voyage]]''. According to the programme, Austin typically consumed in excess of 29,000 [[calories]] a day – over ten times the average daily intake for a UK male, and has major health problems as a result of his [[morbid obesity]]. He also claimed to drink up to 40 pints on a night out. A previous documentary on Britain's heaviest men – ''The Fattest Men in Britain'' – which saw Austin take the crown, though he was notably lighter and more mobile at the time, reported that he led an actively social life and was something of a celebrity on the [[Birmingham]] club circuit, and a very visible supporter of [[Birmingham City F.C.]] at their home games. However, he was unable to attend their victorious [[Wembley Stadium]] appearance on 27 February 2011, when they lifted the [[Football League Cup]] with a 2–1 win over [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in the [[2011 Football League Cup Final|final]] as he was too big to get a seat. By this stage he weighed 40 stone.<ref>{{cite web|last=Marsden |first=John |url=http://www.birminghammail.net/news/top-stories/2011/02/14/birmingham-city-fan-big-barry-austin-set-to-miss-wembley-97319-28165062/ |title=Birmingham City fan Big Barry Austin set to miss Wembley – Top Stories – News |publisher=Birmingham Mail |date= |accessdate=2011-11-03}}</ref>
According to both documentaries, Austin's greatest problem is his legs (which have notably reduced his mobility in the latter programme). Starved of blood because of their enormous size and distance from his heart, they cause him to suffer regular terrible bacterial infections that leave him swollen, in agony and immobile at home. In September 2005, Austin committed himself to losing weight, restricting his daily intake to a mere 1,500 calories in a bid to save his life.
In November 2009 it was reported that Austin currently weighed 40 stone and was starting a new diet plan to try to lose at least 10 stone. The report also gave his peak weight as 65 stone.<ref>[http://www.sundaymercury.net/news/midlands-news/2009/11/15/40st-birmingham-city-fan-barry-austin-is-copying-diet-used-by-friends-star-jennifer-anistond-diet-66331-25168132/ 40st Birmingham City fan Barry Austin is copying diet used by Friends star Jennifer Aniston diet], ''Sunday Mercury'', November 15, 2009</ref>
In December 2009 Austin played 'Big Brian' in [[ITV1]]'s comedy-drama ''[[The Fattest Man in Britain]]'' starring [[Timothy Spall]] and [[Bobby Ball]].<ref>[http://www.comedy.org.uk/guide/tv/the_fattest_man_in_britain/ The Fattest Man In Britain] on The British Comedy Guide website</ref>
In February 2012 it was confirmed that Barry would be getting married to long term partner of 13 years and former Britain’s fattest woman contestant, "Big Debs" Debbie Kirby.<ref>{{cite news |date=19 February 2012 |author=Adam Aspinall |title=Barry Austin is to get married to his long term love |newspaper=Sunday Mercury |accessdate=2012-03-02 |url=http://www.sundaymercury.net/news/midlands-news/2012/02/19/barry-austin-is-to-get-married-to-his-long-term-love-66331-30358006/ |archivedate=2012-03-02 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65rM79YaA?url=http://www.sundaymercury.net/news/midlands-news/2012/02/19/barry-austin-is-to-get-married-to-his-long-term-love-66331-30358006/ |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==See also==
*[[List of the heaviest people]]

{{wiktionary|Borvo}} In [[Lusitanian mythology|Lusitanian]] and [[Celtic polytheism]], '''Borvo''' (also known variously as '''Bormo''', '''Bormanus''', '''Bormanicus''', '''Borbanus''', '''Boruoboendua''', '''Vabusoa''', '''Labbonus''' or '''Borus''') was the Celtic God of Minerals and healing [[deity]] associated with bubbling [[spring (hydrosphere)|spring]] [[water]].<ref name="autogenerated1">[http://www.sacred-texts.com/neu/celt/rac/rac06.htm The Religion of the Ancient Celts: Chapter III. The Gods of Gaul and the Continental Celts<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Centres of worship== In [[Gaul]], he was particularly worshipped at [[Bourbonne-les-Bains]], in the territory of the [[Lingones]], where ten inscriptions are recorded. Two other inscriptions are recorded, one (CIL 13, 02901) from [[Entrains-sur-Nohain]]<ref name="CIL13"/> and the other (CIL 12, 02443) from [[Aix-en-Savoie]] in [[Gallia Narbonensis]].<ref>[[Corpus Inscriptionum Latinarum]] (CIL), '''12''': ''Gallia Narbonensis''.</ref> Votive tablets inscribed ‘Borvo’ show that the offerers desired healing for themselves or others.<ref name="autogenerated1" /> Many of the sites where offerings to Borvo have been found are in [[Gaul]]: inscriptions to him have been found in [[Drôme]] at [[Aix-en-Diois]], [[Bouches-du-Rhône]] at [[Aix-en-Provence]], [[Gers]] at [[Auch]], [[Allier]] at [[Bourbon-l'Archambault]], [[Savoie]] at [[Aix-les-Bains]], [[Saône-et-Loire]] at [[Bourbon-Lancy]], in [[Savoie]] at [[Aix-les-Bains]], [[Haute-Marne]] at [[Bourbonne-les-Bains]] and in [[Nièvre]] at [[Entrains-sur-Nohain]].<ref name="autogenerated2">[http://www.mythofrancaise.asso.fr/mythes/themes/divcelt2.htm]</ref> However, findings have also been uncovered in the [[Netherlands]] at [[Utrecht (city)|Utrecht]],<ref>Garrett S. Olmsted, "The gods of the Celts and the Indo-Europeans", page 427</ref> where he is called Boruoboendua Vabusoa Labbonus, and in [[Portugal]] at [[Caldas de Vizella]] and at [[Idanha a Velha]], where he is called Borus and identified with [[Mars (mythology)|Mars]].<ref name="autogenerated2" /> At [[Aix-en-Provence]], he was referred to as Borbanus and Bormanus but at [[Caldas de Vizella]] in [[Portugal]], he was hailed as Bormanicus,<ref name="autogenerated2" /> and at [[Burtscheid]] and at [[Worms, Germany|Worms]] in [[Germany]] as Borbetomagus.
==Epithets== In all of his centers of worship where [[Interpretatio graeca|he was assimilated to a Roman god]], Borvo was equated with [[Apollo]].<ref name="autogenerated2" /> Many local gods were identified with Apollo in his capacity of god of healing.<ref name="autogenerated1" /> He bore similarities to the goddess [[Sirona]], who was also a healing deity associated with mineral springs,<ref>Paul-Marie Duval. 1957-1993. ''Les dieux de la Gaule.'' Presses Universitaires de France / Éditions Payot. Paris.</ref> but he is clearly distinct from her. Variant forms of his name include Bormo and Bormanus (in [[Gaul]]) and Bormanicus (in [[Portugal]]). The names Bormanus, Bormo and Borvo are found on inscriptions as names of river or fountain gods.<ref name="autogenerated3">[http://www.sacred-texts.com/neu/celt/rac/rac15.htm The Religion of the Ancient Celts: Chapter XII. River and Well Worship<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Divine entourage== Borvo was frequently associated with a divine consort. Eight of the inscriptions mention the goddess [[Damona]]. Here is an example of one of them (CIL 13, 05911):
:''Deo Apol/lini Borvoni / et Damonae / C(aius) Daminius / Ferox civis / Lingonus ex / voto''<ref name="CIL13">[[Corpus Inscriptionum Latinarum]] (CIL), '''13''': ''Tres Galliae et Germanae''.</ref>
In other areas, Borvo's partner is the goddess [[Bormana]]. Bormana was, in some areas, worshipped independently of her male counterpart.<ref>Miranda Green. ''Dictionary of Celtic Myth and Legend.'' Thames and Hudson Ltd. London. 1997</ref> Gods like Borvo, and others, equated with Apollo, presided over healing springs, and they are usually associated with goddesses, as their husbands or sons.<ref name="autogenerated3" /> He is found in [[Drôme]] at [[Aix-en-Diois]] with [[Bormana]] and in [[Saône-et-Loire]] at [[Bourbon-Lancy]] and in [[Haute-Marne]] at [[Bourbonne-les-Bains]] with [[Damona]] but he is accompanied by the ‘candid spirit’ [[Candidus (Celtic spirit)|Candidus]] in [[Nièvre]] at [[Entrains-sur-Nohain]].<ref name="autogenerated2" /> In the [[Netherlands]] at [[Utrecht (city)|Utrecht]] as '''Boruoboendua''' '''Vabusoa''' '''Lobbonus,''' he is found in the company of an [[Ogmios|Celtic Hercules]], [[Macusanus]] and [[Baldruus]].<ref name="autogenerated2" />
==Etymology== The variants ''Borus ~ Borvo ~ Bormo ~ Bormanus'' seem to be based on a root *''boru''-. This root in turn is thought to be a variant of the [[Proto-Celtic]] root *''beru''- ‘boil’ and may have meant ‘to bubble.’ Cognate with the names is the [[Welsh language|Welsh]] ''berw'' ‘boiling.’<ref name="autogenerated1" /> and the [[Goidelic]] ''bruich'', ‘boil, cook’.<ref>[http://www.ceantar.org/Dicts/MB2/mb05.html#bruich MacBain's Dictionary - Section 5<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The words are variants of a [[Proto-Indo-European language|Proto-Indo-European]] base *''bhreue''- ‘to bubble, boil, effervesce’ (cf. Skt. ''Bhurnih'' ‘violent, passionate,’ Gk. ''Phrear'' ‘well, spring,’ L. ''fervere'' ‘to boil, foam,’ Thracian Gk. ''Brytos'' ‘fermented liquor made from barley;’ O.E. ''beorma'' ‘yeast;’ O.H.G. ''brato'' ‘roast meat’ ) from which the [[English language|English]] [[word]] ''brew'' also derives.<ref>[http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?search=brew&searchmode=none Online Etymology Dictionary<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The [[Proto-Celtic]] forms of the name variants most probably were *''Boru-s'', *''Borwon''-, *''Borumāno-s'' and *''Borumān-iko-s'' and the names most probably meant the ‘Bubbler.’ The base of these names is furthermore the source of the name of the [[River Barrow]]. In [[Irish language|Irish]], the river is called ''[[River Barrow|Bearú]]'', the ‘Boiling, Bubbling’ and in [[Irish mythology]] it was [[Dian Cecht]], a great healer of the [[Tuatha Dé Danann]], who first caused the river to ‘boil’.<ref>[http://www.sacred-texts.com/neu/celt/cml/cml09.htm Celtic Myth and Legend: The Gaelic Gods: Chapter V. The Gods of the Gaels<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> *''Borvo''- is the stem Macbain reconstructs for the [[Irish language|Irish]] ''borbhan'', ‘a purling sound,’ and which he also relates to the Welsh ''berw'', ‘seethe,’ French ''[[Bourbon l'Archambault|Bourbon]]'' and the Latin ''fervo'', ‘boil’.<ref>[http://www.ceantar.org/Dicts/MB2/mb04.html#borbhan MacBain's Dictionary - Section 4<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

'''Bundled payment''', also known as '''episode-based payment''', '''episode payment''', '''episode-of-care payment''', '''case rate''', '''evidence-based case rate''', '''global bundled payment''', '''global payment''', '''package pricing''', or '''packaged pricing''', is defined as the reimbursement of [[health care provider]]s (such as hospitals and physicians) "on the basis of expected costs for {{Sic|hide=y|clinically|-}}defined episodes of care."<ref name="Cromwell-1997">{{Cite journal| vauthors= Cromwell J, Dayhoff DA, Thoumaian AH | title = Cost savings and physician responses to global bundled payments for Medicare heart bypass surgery | journal = Health Care Financ Rev | volume = 19 | issue = 1 | pages = 41–57 | year = 1997 | url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0795/is_n1_v19/ai_20750869/ | pmid = 10180001 }}</ref><ref name="Miller-2008">{{Cite news | url= http://managedhealthcareexecutive.modernmedicine.com/mhe/Cover+Article/Package-pricing-Geisingers-new-model-holds-the-pro/ArticleStandard/Article/detail/522495 | author= Miller J | title= Package pricing: Geisinger's new model holds the promise of aligning payment with optimal care | newspaper= Managed Healthcare Executive | date= 1 June 2008 | accessdate= 2010-03-11 | archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20101001223614/http://managedhealthcareexecutive.modernmedicine.com/mhe/Cover+Article/Package-pricing-Geisingers-new-model-holds-the-pro/ArticleStandard/Article/detail/522495# | archive-date= 2010-10-01 | dead-url= yes | df= }}</ref><ref name="MA-2009a">{{Cite web|url= http://www.mass.gov/Eeohhs2/docs/dhcfp/pc/Final_Report/Appendix%20C%20-%20Payment%20Models%20&%20Comp%20Strategies.pdf | author = Commonwealth of Massachusetts, Special Commission on the Health Care Payment System | title= Recommendations of the Special Commission on the Health Care Payment System. Appendix C: memos on basic payment models and complementary payment-related strategies| date=16 July 2009 |accessdate=2010-03-11}}</ref><ref name="Satin-2009">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=2009|title=Performance-based bundled payments: potential benefits and burdens|url=https://p4presearch.dl.umn.edu/sites/g/files/pua991/f/media/mn_med_bundles_special_report_-_satin.pdf|journal=Minn Med|volume=92|issue=10|pages=33–5|doi=|pmid=19916270|access-date=|via=|vauthors=Satin DJ, Miles J}}</ref><ref name="Miller-2009">{{Cite journal | author = Miller HD | title = From volume to value: better ways to pay for health care | journal = Health Aff (Millwood) | volume = 28 | issue = 5 | pages = 1418–28 | year = 2009 | doi = 10.1377/hlthaff.28.5.1418 | url = http://healthaff.highwire.org/cgi/content/full/28/5/1418 | pmid = 19738259 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130415002809/http://healthaff.highwire.org/cgi/content/full/28/5/1418 | archivedate = 2013-04-15 | df = }}</ref> It has been described as "a middle ground" between [[fee-for-service]] reimbursement (in which providers are paid for each service rendered to a patient) and [[Capitation (healthcare)|capitation]] (in which providers are paid a "lump sum" per patient regardless of how many services the patient receives), given that risk is shared between payer and provider.<ref name="RAND-2009">{{Cite web|url= http://www.randcompare.org/policy-options/bundled-payment| author = RAND Corporation | title= Overview of bundled payment| accessdate=2010-03-11}}</ref> Bundled payments have been proposed in the [[health care reform debate in the United States]] as a strategy for reducing [[health care prices in the United States|health care costs]], especially [[Health care reforms proposed during the Obama administration|during the Obama administration]] (2009–2016).<ref name="Obama-2009a">{{Cite web |url= http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/Remarks-by-the-President-to-the-Annual-Conference-of-the-American-Medical-Association |title= Remarks by the President at the annual conference of the American Medical Association |author= Obama B |date= 15 June 2009 |accessdate= 2010-03-11 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20100313084300/http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/Remarks-by-the-President-to-the-Annual-Conference-of-the-American-Medical-Association/# |archive-date= 2010-03-13 |dead-url= yes |df= }}</ref> Commercial payers have shown interest in bundled payments in order to reduce costs.<ref name=cg/> In 2012, it was estimated that approximately one-third of the United States healthcare reimbursement used bundled methodology.<ref name=cg3>{{cite web| url=http://www.thecamdengroup.com/thought-leadership/top-ten/top-10-considerations-for-clinical-service-line-leaders/| title=Top 10 Considerations for Clinical Service Line Leaders| date=July 2012| author=Deirdre Baggot| publisher=GE Healthcare Camden Group| access-date=June 13, 2016}}</ref>
==History== In the mid-1980s, it was believed that [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]]'s hospital prospective payment system with [[diagnosis-related group]]s may have led to hospitals' discharging patients to post-hospital care (such as [[Nursing home|skilled nursing facilities]]) more quickly than was appropriate to save money.<ref name="Neu-1986">{{Cite web|url= http://www.rand.org/pubs/reports/2009/R3335.pdf |title= Extending the Medicare prospective payment system to posthospital care. Planning a demonstration |vauthors=Neu CR, Palmer A, Henry DP, Olson GT, Harrison S |date=May 1986|publisher=RAND Corporation |location=Santa Monica, CA |accessdate=2010-03-11}}</ref> It was therefore suggested that Medicare bundle payments for hospital and posthospital care;<ref name="Neu-1986"/> however, despite favorable analyses of the idea,<ref name="Welch-1998">{{Cite journal | author = Welch WP | title = Bundled Medicare payment for acute and postacute care | journal = Health Aff (Millwood) | volume = 17 | issue = 6 | pages = 69–81 | year = 1998 | url = http://healthaff.highwire.org/cgi/reprint/17/6/69.pdf | pmid = 9916356 | doi = 10.1377/hlthaff.17.6.69 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name="CBO-2008">{{Cite book|title= Budget options. Volume I. Health care |chapter= Chapter 5. The quality and efficiency of health care. Option 30. Bundle payments for hospital care and post-acute care |author= Congressional Budget Office | date =December 2008|publisher= Congress of the United States |location=Washington, DC |pages=62–63 |url= http://www.cbo.gov/ftpdocs/99xx/doc9925/12-18-HealthOptions.pdf |accessdate=2010-03-11}}</ref> it had not been implemented, as of 2009.<ref name="PostAcute-2009">{{Cite web|url= http://www.post-acute.org/bundling/Bundling%20Report%20V15.pdf|title= Bundling payment for post-acute care: building blocks and policy options| author=Center for Post-acute Studies|year=2009|publisher=National Rehabilitation Hospital|location=Washington, DC|accessdate=2010-03-11}}</ref>
Bundled payments began as early as 1984, when [[The Texas Heart Institute]], under the direction of [[Denton Cooley]], began to charge flat fees for both hospital and physician services for cardiovascular surgeries.<ref name="Miller-2009"/><ref name="Edmonds-1995">{{Cite journal|vauthors=Edmonds C, Hallman GL | title = CardioVascular Care Providers. A pioneer in bundled services, shared risk, and single payment | journal = Tex Heart Inst J | volume = 22 | issue = 1 | pages = 72–6 | year = 1995 | pmid = 7787473 | pmc=325213}}</ref> Authors from the Institute claimed that its approach "maintain[ed] a high quality of care" while lowering costs (in 1985, the flat fee for [[coronary artery bypass surgery]] at the Institute was $13,800 as opposed to the average Medicare payment of $24,588).<ref name="Edmonds-1995"/>
Another early experience with bundled payments occurred between 1987 and 1989, involving an [[orthopedic surgery|orthopedic surgeon]], a hospital ([[Ingham Regional Medical Center]]), and a [[health maintenance organization]] (HMO) in Michigan.<ref name="Miller-2009"/><ref name="Johnson-1994">{{Cite journal|vauthors=Johnson LL, Becker RL | title = An alternative health-care reimbursement system -- application of arthroscopy and financial warranty: results of a 2-year pilot study | journal = Arthroscopy | volume = 10 | issue = 4 | pages = 462–70; discussion 471–2 | year = 1994 | doi = 10.1016/S0749-8063(05)80200-2 | url = http://www.arthroscopyjournal.org/article/S0749-8063%2805%2980200-2/abstract | pmid = 7945644}}</ref> The HMO referred 111 patients to the surgeon for possible surgery; the surgeon would evaluate each patient for free.<ref name="Johnson-1994"/> The surgeon and the hospital received a predetermined fee for any [[arthroscopy|arthroscopic]] surgery performed, but they also provided a two-year [[warranty]] in that they promised to cover any post-surgery expenses (for example, four re-operations) instead of the HMO.<ref name="Johnson-1994"/> Under this arrangement, "all parties benefitted financially": the HMO paid $193,000 instead of the $318,538 expected; the hospital received $96,500 instead of the $84,892 expected; and the surgeon and his associates received $96,500 instead of the $51,877 expected.<ref name="Johnson-1994"/>
In 1991, a "Medicare Participating Heart Bypass Center Demonstration" began in four hospitals across the United States; three other hospitals were added to the project in 1993, and the project concluded in 1996.<ref name="Cromwell-1997"/><ref name="Cromwell-1998">{{Cite web|url= http://www.cms.hhs.gov/DemoProjectsEvalRpts/downloads/Medicare_Heart_Bypass_Executive_Summary.pdf |title= Medicare Participating Heart Bypass Demonstration. Executive summary. Final report |vauthors=Cromwell J, Dayhoff DA, McCall NT, Subramanian S, Freitas RC, Hart RJ, Caswell C, Stason W |date=1998-07-24 |publisher=Health Economics Research, Inc |location=Waltham, MA |accessdate=2010-03-11}}</ref> In the demonstration, Medicare paid global inpatient hospital and physician rates for hospitalizations for coronary artery bypass surgery; the rates included any related readmissions.<ref name="Cromwell-1997"/> Among the published evaluations of the project were the following: * In a 1997 analysis, it was estimated that in 1991-1993, the original four hospitals would have had expenditures of $110.8 million for coronary artery bypasses for Medicare beneficiaries, but the change in reimbursement methodology saved $15.31 million for Medicare and $1.84 million for Medicare beneficiaries and their supplemental insurers, for a total savings of $17.2 million (15.5%).<ref name="Cromwell-1997"/> Of the total savings, 85%-93% was attributable to inpatient savings and another 6%-11% was attributable to postdischarge savings; furthermore, there was "no diminution in quality."<ref name="Cromwell-1997"/> * A 1998 report to the Health Care Financing Administration (now known as the [[Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services]]) noted that in the five years of the demonstration project, the seven hospitals would have had expenditures of $438 million for coronary artery bypasses for Medicare beneficiaries, but the change in reimbursement methodology saved $42.3 million for Medicare and $7.9 million for Medicare beneficiaries and their supplemental insurers, for a total savings of $50.3 million (11.5%).<ref name="Cromwell-1998"/> In addition, controlling for patient risk factors, the inpatient mortality rate in the demonstration hospitals declined over the course of the project.<ref name="Cromwell-1998"/> The negative aspects of the project included difficulties in billing and collection.<ref name="Cromwell-1998"/> * A 2001 paper examining three of the original four hospitals with comparable "micro-cost" data determined that "the cost reductions primarily came from nursing intensive care unit, routine nursing, pharmacy, and catheter lab."<ref name="Liu-2001">{{Cite journal|vauthors=Liu CF, Subramanian S, Cromwell J | title = Impact of global bundled payments on hospital costs of coronary artery bypass grafting | journal = J Health Care Finance | volume = 27 | issue = 4 | pages = 39–54 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11434712 }}</ref>
By 2001, "case rates for episodes of illness" (bundled payments) were recognized as one type of "blended payment method" (combining retrospective and prospective payment) along with "capitation with fee-for-service carve-outs" and "specialty budgets with fee-for-service or 'contact' capitation."<ref name="Robinson-2001">{{Cite journal| author = Robinson JC| title = Theory and practice in the design of physician payment incentives | journal = Milbank Q | volume = 79 | issue = 2 | pages = 149–77 | year = 2001 | url = http://www.milbank.org/quarterly/7902feat.html | pmid = 11439463 | pmc=2751195 | doi=10.1111/1468-0009.00202}}</ref> In subsequent years, other blended methods of payment have been proposed such as "comprehensive care payment",<ref name="Miller-2009"/> "comprehensive payment for comprehensive care",<ref name="Goroll-2007">{{Cite journal|vauthors=Goroll AH, Berenson RA, Schoenbaum SC, Gardner LB | title = Fundamental reform of payment for adult primary care: comprehensive payment for comprehensive care | journal = J Gen Intern Med | volume = 22 | issue = 3 | pages = 410–5 | year = 2007 | doi = 10.1007/s11606-006-0083-2 | pmid=17356977 | pmc=1824766}}</ref> and "complete chronic care"<ref name="HC4HR-2009">{{Cite web|url= http://newamerica.net/files/DeliverySystemWhitePaper.pdf |title= Realigning U.S. health care incentives to better serve patients and taxpayers |author = Health CEOs for Health Reform|date=12 June 2009|location= Washington, DC |publisher= New America Foundation |accessdate=2010-03-13}}</ref> which incorporate payment for keeping people as healthy as possible in addition to payment for episodes of illness.
The St. Joseph Hospital in Denver held an acute-care episode (ACE) demonstration project in 2003, administered by Deirdre Baggot. Based on the Medicare Prescription Drug Improvement and Modernization Act, the ACE demonstration bundled Parts A and B of Medicare for episodes of care.<ref name=mh/>
In 2006-2007, the [[Geisinger Health System]] tested a "ProvenCare" model for coronary artery bypass surgery that included [[best practices]], patient engagement, and "preoperative, inpatient, and postoperative care [rehospitalizations] within 90 days... packaged into a fixed price."<ref name="Casale-2007">{{Cite journal|vauthors=Casale AS, Paulus RA, Selna MJ, Doll MC, Bothe AE Jr, McKinley KE, Berry SA, Davis DE, Gilfillan RJ, Hamory BH, Steele GD Jr |title='ProvenCare<sup>SM</sup>': a provider-driven pay-for-performance program for acute episodic cardiac surgical care |journal=Ann Surg |volume=246 |issue=4 |pages=613-21; discussion 621-3 |year=2007 |doi=10.1097/SLA.0b013e318155a996 |url=http://www.geisinger.org/provencare/as_pc.pdf |pmid=17893498 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100827070337/http://www.geisinger.org/provencare/as_pc.pdf |archivedate=2010-08-27 |df= }}</ref> The program received national attention including articles in ''[[The New York Times]]'' <ref name="Abelson-2009">{{Cite news|title= In bid for better care, surgery with a warranty |author=Abelson R |newspaper=The New York Times |date= 17 May 2007 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/17/business/17quality.html |accessdate=2010-03-11}}</ref> and the ''[[New England Journal of Medicine]]''<ref name="Lee-2007">{{Cite journal|author=Lee TH |title=Pay for performance, version 2.0? |journal=N Engl J Med |volume=357 |issue=6 |pages=531–3 |year=2007 |doi=10.1056/NEJMp078124 |url=http://www.geisinger.org/provencare/nejm_pc.pdf |pmid=17687128 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100827070457/http://www.geisinger.org/provencare/nejm_pc.pdf |archivedate=2010-08-27 |df= }}</ref> in mid-2007. An evaluation published in late 2007 showed that 117 patients who received "ProvenCare" had a significantly shorter total length of stay (resulting in 5% lower [[charge description master|hospital charges]]), a greater likelihood of being discharged to home, and a lower readmission rate compared with 137 patients who received conventional care in 2005.<ref name="Casale-2007"/>
The [[Robert Wood Johnson Foundation]] gave grants beginning in 2007 for a bundled payment project called PROMETHEUS ("Provider payment Reform for Outcomes, Margins, Evidence, Transparency, Hassle-reduction, Excellence, Understandability and Sustainability") Payment.<ref name="Gosfield-2007">{{Cite web|url= http://www.rwjf.org/files/research/makingitreal.pdf |title= Making PROMETHEUS In July 2009, a Special Commission on the Health Care Payment System in Massachusetts distinguished between episode-based payments (i.e., bundled payments) and "global payments" that were defined as "fixed-dollar payments for the care that patients may receive in a given time period... plac[ing] providers at financial risk for both the occurrence of medical conditions and the management of those conditions."<ref name="MA-2009a"/> The Commission recommended that global payments "with adjustments to reward provision of accessible and high quality care" (not bundled payments) be used for Massachusetts health care providers.<ref name="MA-2009b">{{Cite web|url= http://www.mass.gov/Eeohhs2/docs/dhcfp/pc/Final_Report/Final_Report.pdf| author = Commonwealth of Massachusetts, Special Commission on the Health Care Payment System | title= Recommendations of the Special Commission on the Health Care Payment System | date=16 July 2009 |accessdate=2010-03-11}}</ref> Among the reasons for selecting global payment were its potential to reduce episodes of care and previous experience with this payment method in Massachusetts.<ref name="MA-2009b"/>
As of 2010, provisions for bundled payments are included in both the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] and the [[Affordable Health Care for America Act]].<ref name="KFF">{{Cite web |url= http://www.kff.org/healthreform/upload/housesenatebill_final.pdf |title= Side-by-side comparison of major health care reform proposals |author= Henry J. Health Reform GPS: a Joint Project of the George Washington University and the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation. http://healthreformgps.org/resources/bundled-payments-%E2%80%93-medicare-pilot-program/.</ref> which is consistent with the Obama proposal.<ref name="KFF"/> The latter bill requires "a plan to reform Medicare payments for post-acute services, including bundled payments."<ref name="KFF"/> 450 healthcare organizations participated in the Bundled Payments for Care Improvement (BPCI) initiative held by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services. The program tested the ability of bundling payments for services as a method for improving quality and lowering costs.<ref name=mh>{{cite web| url=http://www.modernhealthcare.com/article/20130131/NEWS/301319949| title=More than 450 provider organizations join payment-bundling initiative| author=Jessica Zigmond| date=January 31, 2013| publisher=Modern Healthcare| access-date=June 13, 2016}}</ref> In June 2016, CMS announced it would be extending the program for two more years.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.acc.org/latest-in-cardiology/articles/2016/06/10/11/12/business-consult| title=Business Consult: CMS is Upping its Bet on Bundled Payments Deirdre Baggot, PhD, MBA, RN, Former Expert Reviewer, Bundled Payments for Care Improvement Initiative at CMS Former Lead, CMS Acute Care Episode (ACE) Demonstration Principal, ECG Management Consultants| date=June 1, 2016| publisher=American College of Cardiology| access-date=August 18, 2016}}</ref>
In July 2015, Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services announced its proposal to mandate a 90-day bundled payment model as a new program for Medicare beneficiaries undergoing joint replacement called the Comprehensive Care for Joint Replacement initiative. The initiative is based on the Bundled Payments for Care Improvement program launched in 2011 and research from the Acute Care Episode demonstration project. The new program will improve cost efficiencies, patient outcomes, and collaboration among providers for an episode of care. Bundled payments will eliminate the demand for unnecessary testing and treatments.<ref>{{cite journal| journal=Healthcare Financial Management: Journal of the Healthcare Financial Management Association| date=October 1, 2015|author1=Deirdre Baggot |author2=Andy Edeburn | title=Mandated Bundled Payments Compel Hospitals to Rethink Post-Acute Care}}</ref> In July 2016, CMS announced three new bundles, referred to as episode payment models (EPMs) aimed at cardiovascular care procedures including acute myocardial infarction (AMI), coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) and hip/ femur fractures. The new model will go into effect on July 1, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ecgmc.com/thought-leadership/articles/cms-targets-cardiovascular-care-with-new-mandatory-bundles|title=CMS Targets Cardiovascular Care with New Mandatory Bundles|publisher=CardioSource World News|first1=Deirdre |last=Baggot|first2=Tori |last2=Manis|date=September 15, 2016|access-date=October 26, 2016}}</ref>
In January 2018, The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation (CMMI) introduced the successor to the BPCI program, BPCI Advanced, which is a voluntary episode payment model that will start on October 1, 2018 and run through December 31, 2023.
According to CMS’ FAQ<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://innovation.cms.gov/Files/x/bpci-advanced-faqs.pdf|title=Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services|last=|first=|date=2018-05-18|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> on the program, “There are two categories of Participants under BPCI Advanced:<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://innovation.cms.gov/initiatives/bpci-advanced|title=BPCI Advanced {{!}} Center for Medicare & Medicaid Innovation|website=innovation.cms.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-05-24}}</ref> Convener Participants and Non-Convener Participants. A Convener Participant is a type of Participant that brings together multiple downstream entities referred to as “Episode Initiators”—which must be either Acute Care Hospitals (ACHs) or Physician Group Practices (PGPs)—to participate in BPCI Advanced, facilitates coordination among them, and bears and apportions financial risks.”
==Advantages== Advocates of bundled payments note: * 25 to 30 percent of hospital procedures are wasteful without improving the quality of care.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.npr.org/sections/money/2013/11/27/247531043/hospital-puts-docs-on-the-spot-to-lower-costs| title=Hospital Puts Docs On the Spot to Lower Costs| date=November 27, 2013| author=Lisa Chow| publisher=NPR| access-date=June 13, 2016}}</ref> Unlike fee-for-service, bundled payment discourages unnecessary care, encourages coordination across providers, and potentially improves quality.<ref name="Miller-2009"/><ref name=cg2>{{cite web| url=http://www.thecamdengroup.com/thought-leadership/top-ten/bundled-payments-revisited-10-new-critical-success-factors/| title=Bundled Payments Revisited: 10 New Critical Success Factors| date=April 2011| author=Deirdre Baggot| publisher=GE Healthcare Camden Group| access-date=June 13, 2016}}</ref> * Unlike capitation, bundled payment does not penalize providers for caring for sicker patients.<ref name="Miller-2009"/> * Considering the advantages and disadvantages of fee-for-service, [[Pay for performance (healthcare)|pay for performance]], bundled payment for episodes of care, and global payment such as capitation, Mechanic and Altman concluded that "episode payments are the most immediately viable approach."<ref name="Mechanic-2009">{{Cite journal| vauthors= Mechanic RE, Altman SH | title = Payment reform options: episode payment is a good place to start | journal = Health Aff (Millwood) | volume = 28 | issue = 2 | pages = w262-71 | year = 2009 | doi = 10.1377/hlthaff.28.2.w262 | url = http://content.healthaffairs.org/cgi/content/full/28/2/w262 | pmid = 19174388 }}</ref> * Researchers from the [[RAND Corporation]] estimated that "national health care spending could be reduced by 5.4% between 2010 and 2019" if the PROMETHEUS model for bundled payment for selected conditions and procedures were widely used.<ref name="Hussey-2009">{{Cite journal| vauthors= Hussey PS, Eibner C, Ridgely MS, McGlynn EA | title = Controlling U.S. health care spending--separating promising from unpromising approaches | journal = N Engl J Med | volume = 361 | issue = 22 | pages = 2109–11 | year = 2009 | doi = 10.1056/NEJMp0910315 | url = http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/full/361/22/2109 | pmid = 19907037 }}</ref> This figure was higher than for seven other possible methods of reducing national health expenditures.<ref name="Hussey-2009"/> In addition, RAND found that bundled payments would decrease financial risk to consumers and would decrease waste.<ref name="RAND">{{Cite web|url= http://www.randcompare.org/policy-options/bundled-payment |author = RAND COMPARE (Comprehensive Assessment of Reform Efforts) | title= Overview of bundled payment |publisher= RAND Corporation |accessdate=2010-03-13}}</ref> * Bundling payment provides additional advantages to providers and patients alike, through removing inefficiency and redundancy from patient-care protocols; e.g. duplicate testing, delivering unnecessary care, and failing to adequately provide postoperative care.<ref name=cg2/> * This method of payment can also provide transparency for consumers by fixing pricing and publishing cost and outcomes data. Patients would be able to choose a provider based on a comparison of real data, not word of mouth.<ref name=cg2/> * Bundled payments may also encourage economies of scale - especially if providers agree to use a single product or type of medical supply - as hospitals or integrated health systems can often negotiate better prices if they purchase supplies in bulk.<ref>[http://www.physicianspractice.com/physician-compensation/bundled-payments-what-physicians-need-know "Bundled Payments: What Physicians Need to Know"] Shelly K. Schwartz, Physicians Practice, November 2012.</ref>
==Considerations== Before practices choose to participate in bundled payments, they need to be diligent in researching potential episodes of care that would be amenable to this type of reimbursement. Traditionally, physician’s quality monitoring and improvement is managed by the hospital’s nursing sector. Transitioning to a bundled payment methodology shifts accountability back to physicians, thus considerations for their delivery in an acute care episode is essential as well as realigning strategic nursing priorities to enable the needed capacity for care delivery transformation.<ref name=cg/> Once they have selected and defined an episode of care, they should: * Identify all associated costs * List all services provided within the episode of care * Calculate how the care episode would be reimbursed * Identify how many entities would share in reimbursement<ref>[http://www.aafp.org/online/en/home/publications/news/news-now/payment-special-report/20120921specrpt-paymentmodels.html "Taming Payment and Delivery Model Monsters"] Sheri Porter, AAFP News, September 2012.</ref> * Involve physicians in care coordination * Create care delivery models to reduce waste, minimize redundancy, and improve provider communication<ref name=cg>{{cite web| url=http://www.thecamdengroup.com/thought-leadership/top-ten/bundled-payments-ten-critical-success-factors/| title=Bundled Payments: Ten Critical Success Factors| date=September 2010| author=Deirdre Baggot| publisher=GE Healthcare Camden Group| access-date=June 13, 2016}}</ref> * Identify the advantages of investing in home care options<ref name=cg3/>
According to a February 2018 ''Health Affairs'' article, Government As Innovation Catalyst: Lessons From The Early Center For Medicare And Medicaid Innovation Models,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.healthaffairs.org/doi/abs/10.1377/hlthaff.2017.1109|title=Government As Innovation Catalyst: Lessons From The Early Center For Medicare And Medicaid Innovation Models|last=|first=|date=2018-05-18|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> “The [BPCI] initiative also highlighted business and operational barriers to implementing this approach. These included managing cash flows, developing budgets for episodes paid prospectively (rather than retrospectively), and reliably tracking providers’ enrollment in a bundled payment model. Convening organizations (such as Premier or Remedy Partners, which brought multiple providers together to support implementation and sometimes shouldered some financial risk), could bring bundles to scale faster but introduced the additional complexity of a three-way arrangement among payer, convener, and provider.”
In Case study: Delivery and payment reform in congestive heart failure at two large academic centers,<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2014-07-01|title=Case study: Delivery and payment reform in congestive heart failure at two large academic centers|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2213076414000359|journal=Healthcare|language=en|volume=2|issue=2|pages=107–112|doi=10.1016/j.hjdsi.2014.04.001|issn=2213-0764}}</ref> published in the July 2014 edition of ''Healthcare: The Journal of Delivery Science and Innovation'', the authors state, “Convening organizations play a key role in providing technical assistance and implementation support. Clinical leaders and health systems do not always have a complete set of tools for payment reform. Thus, conveners contracted by CMMI, played a helpful role in catalyzing payment reform for their members.”
== Design options == Implementation of bundled payments can take many different forms. Several of the key design dimensions include: * Prospective vs. retrospective payment: A prospective bundle pays a fixed price, established in advance, to a provider to deliver all services included within the bundle. A retrospective bundle initially pays each provider for services in the traditional fee-for-service payment method; after the completion of the episode of care, a provider designated as the accountable provider for the bundle receives a share of savings relative to the bundle price or pays a share of costs in excess of the bundle price. Retrospective payment is sometimes called "virtual bundling."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ama-assn.org/ama/pub/advocacy/state-advocacy-arc/state-advocacy-campaigns/private-payer-reform/state-based-payment-reform/evaluating-payment-options/bundled-payments.page|title=Bundled Payments|website=www.ama-assn.org|access-date=2016-09-29}}</ref> * Approach to risk adjustment: bundled payments often use a ''risk adjustment'' approach to modify the price of the bundle to reflect the severity of the patient's condition. Payment methods vary on the basis of which factors are used to determine the risk adjustment (such a patient diagnoses from the past year, patient diagnoses from the past three years, patient medications) and how much each factor adjusts the price of the bundle.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://multimedia.3m.com/mws/media/885503O/3m-bundled-payment-ebook.pdf|title=Bundling payment for episodes of care: Balancing the financial risk of health care|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=3M Health Information Systems|access-date=}}</ref> * Level of risk sharing: a bundled payment may be structured to offer ''upside'' (a share of savings if costs are below the bundle price), ''downside'' (a share of excess costs if costs are above the bundle price), or both. Providers may bear all of the savings and/or excess costs (100% risk), or they may bear a fraction of the risk while payers continue to bear the rest. * Exclusions, tail risk, and stop-loss criteria: Bundled payment models may choose to set up a variety of safeguards that limit the financial risk that providers bear under extreme circumstances. Various forms of these safeguards include criteria excluding certain types of cases (such as patients with serious comorbidities), criteria excluding costs for cases in excess of a cost threshold (such as unusual cases whose cost is more than 3 standard deviations above the average), and stop-loss criteria limiting the downside that a provider will bear if the average cost is far above the bundle price.
==Disadvantages== The drawbacks of a bundled payment approach include: * The scientific evidence in support of it has been described as "scant."<ref name="MA-2009a"/> For example, RAND concluded that its effect on health outcomes is "uncertain."<ref name="RAND"/> * It does not discourage unnecessary episodes of care;<ref name="Miller-2009"/> for example, physicians might hospitalize some patients unnecessarily.<ref name="MedPAC-2008"/> * Providers may seek to maximize profit by avoiding patients for whom reimbursement may be inadequate (e.g., patients who do not take their drugs as prescribed), by overstating the severity of an illness, by giving the lowest level of service possible, by not diagnosing complications of a treatment before the end date of the bundled payment, or by delaying post-hospital care until after the end date of the bundled payment.<ref name="Satin-2009"/><ref name="MedPAC-2008"/> * Hospitals may seek to maximize profit by limiting access to specialists during an inpatient stay.<ref name="Galewitz-2009"/> * Because one provider may [[Outsourcing|outsource]] part of the care of a patient to other providers, it may be difficult to assign financial accountability for a given bundled payment.<ref name="Satin-2009"/> * There is an administrative and operational burden, for example in establishing fair compensation rates.<ref name="Satin-2009"/><ref name="RAND"/> Small sample sizes and incomplete data may cause difficulties in calculation of proper rates for bundled payments.<ref name="Robinson-2009">{{Cite journal| vauthors= Robinson JC, Williams T, Yanagihara D | title = Measurement of and reward for efficiency in California's pay-for-performance program. How the Integrated Healthcare Association discovered the problems of using 'episodes of care' as the basis for physician performance rewards | journal = Health Aff (Millwood) | volume = 28 | issue = 5 | pages = 1438–47 | year = 2009 | doi = 10.1377/hlthaff.28.5.1438 | url = http://content.healthaffairs.org/cgi/content/full/28/5/1438 | pmid = 19738261 }}</ref> If rates are set too high, providers may provide unnecessary services; if rates are set too low, providers may experience financial difficulties or may provide inadequate care.<ref name="Miller-2009"/> * Some types of illnesses may not fall neatly into "episodes."<ref name="MA-2009a"/> * It is possible that one patient may have multiple bundles that overlap each other.<ref name="Robinow-2010">{{Cite web|url= http://www.commonwealthfund.org/~/media/Files/Publications/Fund%20Report/2010/Feb/1373_Robinow_potential_global_payment.pdf |title= The potential of global payment: insights from the field |author = Robinow A |date=February 2010 |location= Washington, DC |publisher= The Commonwealth Fund |accessdate=2010-03-13}}</ref> * [[Medical school in the United States#Academic health centers|Academic health centers]], which emphasize research, teaching, and new technologies, may be disadvantaged by the payment scheme.<ref name="Robinow-2010"/> * Providers risk large losses, for example if a patient experiences a catastrophic event.<ref name="Guterman-2009">{{Cite journal| vauthors= Guterman S, Davis K, Schoenbaum S, Shih A | title = Using Medicare payment policy to transform the health system: a framework for improving performance | journal = Health Aff (Millwood) | volume = 28 | issue = 2 | pages = w238-50 | year = 2009 | doi = 10.1377/hlthaff.28.2.w238 | url = http://content.healthaffairs.org/cgi/content/full/28/2/w238 | pmid = 19174386 }}</ref> A complex "reinsurance mechanism" may be needed to convince providers to accept bundled payments.<ref name="Guterman-2009"/> * A study by [[Geisel School of Medicine|Dartmouth Medical School]] showed extreme variation in healthcare across the U.S. and attributed the inconstancies to a lack of standardized care protocols.<ref name=cg2/> Currently, there is no nationally accepted bundled payment methodology defined, though continued experimentation is expected to lead to refinement.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.orhcnews.com/articles/08-2014/or-dbaggot-0814.php| title=The Bundled Payment Title Wave: Recap and Insight from the Fourth National Bundled Payment Summit| date=July 7, 2014| author=Deirdre Baggot| publisher=Oregon Healthcare News| access-date=June 13, 2016}}</ref>

'''[[Capital punishment]] in the [[Gaza Strip]]''' has been practiced by the [[Hamas Administration in Gaza|Hamas Administration]] since it assumed power in 2007. The punishment is given for offenses such as crimes against [[Islamic law]] (including murder, [[LGBT rights in the State of Palestine|homosexual activities]], etc.), [[Palestinian land laws|land sales to Jews]], and [[treason]]. The [[Hamas]] administration of the Gaza Strip inherited the [[Palestinian National Authority]] code of law, which included the death penalty for several kinds of offenses, but while the Palestinian administration in [[Ramallah]] has refrained from executing capital punishments, death sentences are periodically performed by Hamas.
==History== According to an [[Amnesty International]] report,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org.uk/press-releases/hamas-tortured-and-killed-palestinian-collaborators-during-gaza-conflict-new-report|title=Hamas tortured and killed Palestinian 'collaborators' during Gaza conflict - new report|publisher=[[Amnesty International]]|accessdate=2016-04-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org.uk/files/webfm/Documents/issues/embargoed_report_2015_strangling_necks.pdf|title=‘Strangling Necks’: Abduction, torture and summary killings of Palestinians by Hamas forces during the 2014 Gaza/Israel conflict|publisher=Amnesty International}} May 2015. Retrieved 2016-04-06</ref> 23 Palestinians were executed in the Gaza Strip by Hamas during the 2014 conflict with Israel.<ref name=guardian2015>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/may/27/hamas-executed-palestinians-under-cover-gaza-conflict-amnesty|title=Hamas executed 23 Palestinians under cover of Gaza conflict, says Amnesty|first=Peter|last=Beaumont|date=27 May 2015|publisher=|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=2016-04-06}}</ref> Amnesty claimed that Hamas used the cover of [[2014 Gaza war]] to carry out summary executions, including to “settle scores” against opponents under the pretext they were “collaborators with Israel”.<ref name=guardian2015/>
According to Amnesty, 23 Palestinians were executed by "[[Islamist]] [[terror group]]"<ref name="dailymail" /> Hamas in the course of the 2014 conflict - 16 of them imprisoned from before the conflict.<ref name="dailymail">{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3098254/Hamas-executed-Palestinian-collaborators-AK-47s-hundreds-spectators-including-children-assisting-Israel-Gaza-conflict-reveals-Amnesty-International.html|title=Report: Hamas unlawfully executed ‘collaborators’ in front of hundreds|publisher=[[Daily Mail]]|accessdate=2016-04-06|date=27 May 2015|first=Larisa|last=Brown|first2=Flora|last2=Drury}}</ref> From among the executed, 6 were killed by a firing squad outside a mosque in front of hundreds of spectators including children.
The Palestinian Center for Human Rights reported in December 2015 that Hamas issued nine death sentences in 2015. Hamas had sentenced four Gazans to death during the first weeks of 2016, all on suspicion of spying.<ref name=newsweek2016/>
In February 2016, the armed wing of Palestinian militant group Hamas carried out execution of Mahmoud Ishtiwi - one of the group’s leading commanders, under allegations of gay sex and theft.<ref name=newsweek2016>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/prominent-hamas-commander-was-executed-after-accusations-gay-sex-432343|title=Hamas executed a prominent commander after accusations of gay sex|date=2 March 2016|publisher=[[Newsweek]]|first=Jack|last=Moore|accessdate=2016-04-06}}</ref> Ishtiwi left two wives and three children.
In May 2016, Hamas reportedly executed three men by firing squad and hanging.<ref name=telegraph2016>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/05/31/hamas-begins-executions-in-gaza/|title=Hamas begins executions in Gaza|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|first=Raf|last=Sanchez|date=31 May 2016|accessdate=2016-04-06}}</ref> The execution was performed in the al-Katiba prison. The executed men were convicted for murder. Reportedly, the execution defied protests from the [[United Nations]] and "will likely" deepen tensions with the [[Palestinian government]] in the West Bank.<ref name=telegraph2016/> Hamas defied an agreement with Fatah, the ruling party in the West Bank, by carrying out the executions without the approval of Palestinian President [[Mahmoud Abbas]]. Hamas later announced that 13 additional prisoners are to be executed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/gaza-executions-calls-for-urgent-moratorium-on-death-penalty-as-10-prisoners-await-execution-by-a7060946.html|title=Hamas resumes executions in Gaza|date=2 June 2016|publisher=[[The Independent]]|first=Lizzie|last=Dearden|accessdate=2016-04-06}}</ref>
In April 2017, it was reported that three Palestinians were executed by Hamas in Gaza Strip over alleged collaboration with Israel.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2017/04/06/hamas-executes-palestinians/100111612/|title=Hamas executes 3 Palestinians over Israel ties|publisher=[[Associated Press]] via [[USA Today]]|date=April 6, 2017|accessdate=2016-04-06}}</ref> Reportedly, the men were hanged at a Hamas police compound, as dozens of Hamas leaders and officials watched the killing.
==Executed people== {|class="wikitable" |- ! !Executed person !Date of execution !Crime(s) !Location !Method |- |1 |Atta Najjar<ref name="dailymail"/> |22 August 2014 |Treason |Katiba prison |Unknown |- |2 |Ayman Taha<ref name="dailymail"/> |4 August 2014 |Treason |Unknown |Shot |- |3 |Mahmoud Ishtiwi<ref name=newsweek2016/> |February 2016 |Homosexual activity |Gaza Strip |Firing squad |}
