[[File:Francis J Bradley-2012.png|thumb|Francis J. Bradley, American health physicist, writer and founding member of the Health Physics Society]] '''Francis J. Bradley''' (born 15 January 1926) is an American health physicist, writer and founding member of the [[Health Physics Society]]. ==Life and times== Francis J. "Frank" Bradley was born on 15 January 1926 in [[New York City]], [[Queens|Queens County]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. Bradley’s father was a New York City [[fireman]]. The Bradley family lived in [[Corona, Queens]] New York. Bradley worked his way up to the rank of [[sergeant]] in the [[U.S. Army Air Force]] pulling duty as a [[Air gunner|gunner]] aboard a [[B-29]] bomber and served in the [[Asiatic-Pacific Theater|Pacific Theater of Operations]] during [[World War II]]. Bradley graduated in 1949 from [[Manhattan College]] with a degree in [[electrical engineering]].Cember, H. (June 1989) 1988 Founders Award presented to Francis J. Bradley. Health Physics. 56(6): 811-2. ==AEC Fellowship== In June 1949 Bradley applied for the [[United States Atomic Energy Commission|Atomic Energy Commission]] (AEC) Fellowship in [[Health physics|Radiological Physics]] and passed the examination administered at [[Columbia University]]. While taking the exam he met [[Herman Cember]]. Bradley and Cember passed the test but were delayed in starting the Fellowship as they waited for their [[Q clearance]] to be completed. ==Oak Ridge and Elda E. Anderson== Bradley began his career in health physics and radiological protection when he received an [[United States Atomic Energy Commission|Atomic Energy Commission]] Fellowship grant in Radiological Physics at [[Oak Ridge National Laboratory]].Pratt, Rose Marie. (June 2001). Frank Bradley is Thirty-Eighth Failla Memorial Award Lecturer, Greater New York Chapter, HPS Newsletter. XXIX(6): 14. At Oak Ridge he started in the second class of [[Elda E. Anderson]] with students that included: [[Herman Cember]], [[Allen Brodsky]] and [[Lester Rogers]].Sicherman, Barbara, and Carol Hurd Green (1980). Notable American Women: The Modern Period. Harvard University Press. ==Ohio State University== Francis J. Bradley went on to the [[Ohio State University]] responsible for Radiation Inspection as the Superintendent of Radiation Safety effective 25 May 1953 with an [[annual salary]] of $6,324.00.http://trustees.osu.edu/assets/files/minutes/Archive%20minutes/1953-1956.pdfRyan, Michael T. and Poston, Sr., John W. (2006). A Half Century of Health Physics: 50th Anniversary of the Health Physics Society. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. While at Ohio State, Bradley became a Fallout Shelter Analysis Instructor at the [[University of Pennsylvania]].http://www.jumpjet.info/Emergency-Preparedness/Emergency-Shelters/Radiation-Shelter/Architect_&_Engineering_Activities_in_Shelter_Development.pdf ==New York State== In 1977 Bradley held the position of Principal Radiophysicist, Division of Safety & Health, New York State Department of Labor.http://www.factsofwny.com/sweeney.htm Bradley spent 20 years with the [[New York State]] Department of Labor, Radiological Health Unit as the Principle Radiophysicist.Pitt, David E. (21 November 1987). Radiation Level Is Cut Outside Plant in Queens. New York Times. Bradley was the ANSI N43 Representative for the American Public Health Association in 1985.Oppermann, H.V. (1985). State Weights and Measures Laboratories. U.S. Department of Commerce, National Bureau of Standards. Washington, D.C. ==Health Physics Society== In 1955 while Superintendent of Radiation Safety at [[Ohio State University]] Bradley organized the initial conference of [[health physicist]]s and from this meeting the [[Health Physics Society]] was formed with [[Karl Z. Morgan]] as President, [[Frederick P. Cowan]] as Vice President, and [[Elda E. Anderson]] as Secretary/Treasurer.Walchuk, Mary. (June 2005). The Birth of the HPS: A Look Back. HPS News. XXXIII(6): 1-8. In the midyear issue of [[Science]] the announcement came of the formation new national scientific organization for health physicists at the 3 day Health Physics Conference at Ohio State University in Columbus, Ohio on 14 June 1955.{{cite journal | title=News of Science | journal=Science |date=15 July 1955 | volume=122 | issue=15 July 1955 | pages=112–117 | doi=10.1126/science.122.3159.112|bibcode = 1955Sci...122..112. }}Bronson, Frazier L. (July 1996). From the ABHP Attic. HPS Newsletter. Health Physics Society. *Founding member and Director *Charter member *Life member *Founders Award, 1988 *President, Government Section, 2000 *[[Gioacchino Failla#Failla Memorial Lecture|Failla Memorial Award]], 23 January 2001Failla Memorial Lecture. (2000). Francis J. Bradley. Radiological and Medical Physics Association, and the Greater New York Chapter of the Health Physics Society. New York, NY. In the midyear issue of [[Science (journal)|Science]] the announcement came of the formation new national scientific organization for health physicists at the 3 day Health Physics Conference at Ohio State University in Columbus, Ohio on 14 June 1955.{{cite journal | title=News of Science | journal=Science |date=15 July 1955 | volume=122 | issue=15 July 1955 | pages=112–117|doi=10.1126/science.122.3159.112 |bibcode = 1955Sci...122..112. }} The organization was temporarily named "Health Physics Society", and [[Karl Z. Morgan]] of the Health Physics Division of Oak Ridge National Laboratory was elected interim president. Other interim officers are: * [[Frederick P. Cowan]], Head, Health Physics Division [[Brookhaven National Laboratory]], Upton, N.Y., vice president, and * [[Elda E. Anderson]], director of the education and training department of the Health Physics Division, [[Oak Ridge National Laboratory]], secretary-treasurer. ===First Board of Directors=== Talks regarding the formation of a professional society had been ongoing for several years. The health physicists had decided to form an independent organization rather than attach to an existing group.
Directors of the Health Physics Society included: * [[Herbert Mermagen]], [[University of Rochester]], Rochester, N.Y. * [[Edgar Charles Barnes]], manager of [[industrial hygiene]], [[Westinghouse Atomic Power Division]], [[Bettis Atomic Power Laboratory|Bettis Field]], Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania * [[John W. 'Jack' Healy]], [[General Electric Co.]], Hanford, Washington * [[William Taylor Ham]], professor of biophysics, [[Medical College of Virginia]], Richmond, Virginia * [[C. Maurice Patterson]], [[DuPont#Second World War: 1941 to 1945|DuPont Atomic Energy Plant]], Aiken, S.C. * [[G. W. C. Tait]], Health Physics Branch, [[Atomic Energy of Canada Limited|Atomic Energy Co. of Canada]], Ltd., Chalk River, Ontario, Canada * Francis J. Bradley, superintendent of radiation safety at [[Ohio State University]] and organizer of the first [[Health Physics Society]] Conference * [[Health Physics Society#William Edward Nolan|William E. Nolan]], Radiation Laboratory, [[University of California, Berkeley]], California * [[Walter Dunhan Claus]], (annual salary $12,000), Division of Biology and Medicine, Biophysics Branch, [[U.S. Atomic Energy Commission]], Washington, D.C.Official Register of the United States, 1952. U.S. Civil Service Commission, Washington, D.C. * [[John E. Pickering]], department of [[radiobiology]], [[Randolph Air Force Base#School of Aviation Medicine|School of Aviation Medicine]], [[Randolph Air Force Base]], Texas ==International Atomic Energy Agency== [[File:Francis J Bradley 1961.png|thumb|Turkey 1961. Bradley assisted with the establishment of a national radiation control program for the 1 MW nuclear reactor at Çekmece Nuclear Research and Training Center that went critical on 27 May 1962.]] In 1961 Bradley worked for the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] and went to [[Turkey]] and assisted with the establishment of a national radiation control program for the 1 MW [[nuclear reactor]] at [[ÇNAEM|Çekmece Nuclear Research and Training Center]] that went critical on 27 May 1962. Bradley next went to [[Taiwan]] to help develop the radiation safety program for the country’s first reactor. ==Project Long Shot and Vela Project== Bradley was involved with [[Amchitka#Long Shot test|Project Long Shot]], the underground nuclear tests on [[Amchitka Island]] that is part of the [[Aleutian Islands]]. In 1965 as part of [[Project Vela|Vela Project]] he conducted radiological measurements and performed environmental sampling. ==References== {{reflist}} * * * * {{DEFAULTSORT:Bradley, Francis J.}} [[Category:Health physicists]] [[Category:1926 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Health Physics Society]] [[Category:People from Queens, New York]] [[Category:Scientists from New York City]] [[Category:Manhattan College alumni]] [[Category:Electrical engineers]]

The '''Global Environmental and Occupational Health e-Library''' or '''GeoLibrary''' is a database of occupational safety and health and environmental health training materials and practice tools. The library is divided into three sections: Environmental Health; Occupational Health and Safety; and a specialty library on Road Safety at Work.
The GeoLibrary is a project of the [[WHO collaborating centres in occupational health|Network of Collaborating Centres]] Work Plan in support of the [[World Health Organization]] (“WHO”) strategy “Occupational Health for All,” and is maintained by the Great Lakes Centers for Occupational and Environmental Safety and Health at the [[University of Illinois at Chicago]] School of Public Health. It was created with the following specific aims, to provide:
#Training materials on diseases of occupation and the environment #Training materials on hazards and diseases as they pertain to individual economic sectors #Teaching materials specific to prevention, safety, advocacy, legal and ethical issues, roles of government, etc. #Practice materials for control and prevention
With a focus on training programs and capacity building, the GeoLibrary provides its users with access to complete courses, tutorials/modules, fact sheets, sample/model programs, guidelines and case studies, all within the public domain and free of charge. Resources are available in six languages (English, Spanish, French, Russian, Chinese and Arabic) and come from a variety of sources (international organizations, governmental institutes and agencies, academic institutions, corporations, and unions).
The construction of the library was made possible through a gift from Abbott Fund. Additional support for its creation was provided by the U.S. National Center for Environmental Health, the U.S. National Institutes of Health Fogarty International Center, and [[National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health]] ("NIOSH") Training Program.
In kind support was provided by NIOSH, the U.S. National Institute for Environmental Health Sciences, the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]], the [[Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry|U.S. Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry]], and WHO Collaborating Centres in Occupational Health.
==Environmental Health Materials== The environmental health branch of the GeoLibrary provides training materials, practice tools and capacity-building resources on topics such as environmental disasters, exposure to physical, chemical, biological and waste hazards, environmental health practice, and environmental management.
In January 2010, in response to the Haiti earthquake, the GeoLibrary and the [[Pan American Health Organization]] (“PAHO”) coordinated a request for natural disaster-related training materials from the Network of Collaborating Centres. The result of this collaboration was the timely creation of a library section entitled “Special Focus: Haiti,” which included emergency and disaster response materials in French, English and Spanish.
==Occupational Safety and Health Materials== The occupational safety and health branch of the GeoLibrary provides training materials, practice tools and capacity-building resources in areas such as exposure to physical, psychosocial, chemical, and biological hazards, adverse health effects, and control strategies. It also includes a sub-section focused on the safety and health hazards of different economic sectors.
In 2009, the GeoLibrary collaborated with PAHO to centralize resources related to the Influenza A (H1N1) virus. The result was the creation of a database entry entitled “Hot Topic: H1N1.” Resources included in this section apply to businesses, agricultural workers, educational facilities, health care facilities, laboratory workers, and travel industry workers.
==Specialty: Road Safety at Work== In collaboration with NIOSH, the Specialty: Road Safety at Work branch was added to provide materials related to the prevention of road traffic injuries and deaths while at work. The resources include employer policies and guidance documents on road safety at work, research reports on risk factors for work-related crashes, as well as statistics about worker injuries and fatalities on roads.
==See also== [[Occupational safety and health]]
==External links== * [http://www.geolibrary.org GeoLibrary] * [http://www.uic.edu/sph/glakes/ Great Lakes Centers for Occupational and Environmental Safety and Health] * [http://www.uic.edu/sph/erc/ Illinois Occupational and Environmental Health and Safety Education Research Center] * [https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/ The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH)] * [http://new.paho.org/ Pan American Health Organization (PAHO)] * [http://www.who.int/en/ World Health Organization (WHO)]

{{refimprove|date=January 2017}} Go Texan day sponsored by the [[Texas Department of Agriculture]], whose purpose is to encourage consumers (both within and outside the state of [[Texas]]) to seek and purchase Texas-made products.<ref>http://www.myfoxzone.com/news/backing-small-businesses/335825688</ref>
The GO TEXAN campaign began in 1999 to focus on Texas agricultural products. Later, the campaign expanded to include [[shrimp]] and [[Texas wine]]. In 2003, the [[Texas Legislature]] expanded the program to include Texas-made products of all sorts.
The current GO TEXAN campaign is divided into four general areas: *GO TEXAN Products—Markets fiber, food, horticulture/forestry/produce, livestock, oysters and shrimp, and wine *GO TEXAN Communities—Designates an area as a "Certified Retirement Community" based on its ability to meet the living, employment/volunteer, health, entertainment, education, and safety needs of residents and visitors, and also spotlights rural communities to support and encourage rural tourism *GO TEXAN Restaurants—Links restaurants to Texas-grown or processed food products *GO TEXAN Special Programs—Operates special programs such as the GO TEXAN booth at the [[State Fair of Texas]],<ref>http://www.freestonecountytimesonline.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=17027:state-fair-of-texas-kicks-off-go-texan-pavilion-officially-opens-for-fairgoers&catid=52:community</ref> a website listing of local [[farmers market]]s, and international marketing go Texan day is on Friday February 26
==References== {{reflist}}

[[File:Pharmacie in Paulista Avenue.jpg|thumb|upright=1.4|In some countries, such as [[Brazil]] (photo) and [[France]], more than 20% of all drug sales in units are generic.]] A '''generic drug''' is a [[pharmaceutical drug]] that has the same chemical substance as the drug that was originally developed, patented and innovated. Generic drugs are allowed for sale after the expiry of the [[chemical patent|patent]] of the original drugs. Because the active chemical substance is the same, the medical profile of generics is believed to be equivalent in performance.<ref name=FDA>{{Cite| publisher = [[Center for Drug Evaluation and Research]], [[U.S. Food and Drug Administration]]| title = Generic Drug Facts| accessdate = 2017-11-11| date = 2017-10-06| url = https://www.fda.gov/Drugs/ResourcesForYou/Consumers/BuyingUsingMedicineSafely/GenericDrugs/ucm167991.htm}}</ref><ref name=SciAm>{{Cite web| title = What's the difference between brand-name and generic prescription drugs?| website = Scientific American| accessdate = 2017-11-11| url = https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/whats-the-difference-betw-2004-12-13/}}</ref> The generic drug has the same [[active pharmaceutical ingredient|Active Pharmaceutical Ingredient]] (API) as the original, but it may differ in characteristics such as manufacturing process, [[pharmaceutical formulation|formulation]], [[excipient]]s, color, taste, and packaging.<ref name=SciAm /><ref>[https://www.ndrugs.com Definition of generic drug]</ref>
Although they may not be associated with a particular company, generic drugs are usually subject to government regulations in the countries in which they are dispensed. They are labeled with the name of the manufacturer and a generic non-proprietary name such as the [[United States Adopted Name]] or [[international nonproprietary name|international non-proprietary name]] of the drug. A generic drug must contain the same [[active ingredient]]s as the original brandname formulation. The [[U.S. Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) requires generics to be identical to or within an acceptable [[bioequivalence|bioequivalent]] range of their brandname counterparts, with respect to [[pharmacokinetics|pharmacokinetic]] and [[pharmacodynamics|pharmacodynamic]] properties.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fda.gov/Drugs/ResourcesForYou/Consumers/QuestionsAnswers/ucm100100.htm|title=Food & Drug Administration, Generic Drugs: Questions and Answers|date=January 12, 2010|publisher=[[Food and Drug Administration (United States)|Food and Drug Administration]]|accessdate=2010-02-03}}</ref> (The FDA's use of the word "identical" is a [[statutory interpretation|legal interpretation]], not literal.)
[[Biopharmaceutical]]s, such as [[monoclonal antibodies]], differ biologically from [[small molecule]] drugs. [[Biosimilar]]s have active pharmaceutical ingredients that are almost identical to the original product and are typically regulated under an extended set of rules, but they are not the same since generic drugs as the active ingredients are not the same as those of their reference products.<ref>{{cite web|last1=U.S. Food and Drug Administration|title=Biosimilar and Interchangeable Products|url=https://www.fda.gov/Drugs/DevelopmentApprovalProcess/HowDrugsareDevelopedandApproved/ApprovalApplications/TherapeuticBiologicApplications/Biosimilars/ucm580419.htm#generic|website=www.fda.gov|accessdate=5 May 2018|language=en}}</ref>
In most cases, generic products become available after the [[patent]] protections, afforded to a drug's original developer, expire. Once generic drugs enter the market, competition often leads to substantially lower prices for both the original brandname product and its generic equivalents. In most countries, patents give 20 years of protection. However, many countries and regions, such as the [[European Union]] and the [[United States]],<ref>{{USC|35|154(a)(2)}}</ref> may grant up to five years of additional protection ("patent term restoration") if manufacturers meet specific goals, such as conducting [[clinical trial]]s for pediatric patients.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Pediatric Research Equity Act of 2007|url=http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/DevelopmentApprovalProcess/DevelopmentResources/UCM049870.pdf}}</ref>
Manufacturers, wholesalers, insurers, and drugstores can all increase prices at various stages of production and distribution.<ref name="insider">{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/mar/25/business/la-fi-lazarus-20130326|title=An insider's view of generic-drug pricing|date=March 25, 2013|publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''}}</ref>
In 2014, according to an analysis by the Generic Pharmaceutical Association, generic drugs accounted for 88% of the 4.3 billion prescriptions filled in the United States.<ref name="gphaonline_2011">{{cite web|url=http://www.gphaonline.org/media/wysiwyg/PDF/GPhA_Savings_Report_2015.pdf|title=Generic Drug Savings in the U.S|date=2015|publisher=Generic Pharmaceutical Association (GPhA)|location=Washington, DC|accessdate=16 June 2016}}</ref>{{rp|2}}
"Branded generics" on the other hand are defined by the [[FDA]] and [[NHS]] as "products that are (a) either novel dosage forms of off-patent products produced by a manufacturer that is not the originator of the molecule, or (b) a molecule copy of an off-patent product with a trade name."<ref>{{cite web|title=FAQ on generic drugs|url=https://www.fda.gov/drugs/resourcesforyou/consumers/questionsanswers/ucm100100.htm|website=FDA|publisher=Food and drug administration|accessdate=21 May 2018}}</ref> Since the company making branded generics can spend little on [[research and development]], it is able to spend on marketing alone, thus earning higher profits and driving costs down.<ref>{{cite web|title=FDA White Paper: Generic Drug Prices in the US Are Lower Than Drug Prices in Canada|url=http://www.fda.gov/oc/whitepapers/drugprices.html|website=FDA|publisher=6.US Food and Drug Administration, Office of Planning|accessdate=21 May 2018}}</ref> For example, the largest revenues of [[Ranbaxy]], now owned by [[Sun Pharma]], came from branded generics.<ref>{{cite news|title=Branded Generics: Misunderstood, but Lucrative|url=https://www.pharmacytimes.com/publications/issue/2008/2008-10/2008-10-8707|accessdate=21 May 2018|publisher=Pharmacy Times|date=1 October 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Big Pharma Embraces Branded Generics|url=https://seekingalpha.com/article/233592-big-pharma-embraces-branded-generics?page=2|website=Seeking Alpha|publisher=Seeking alpha|accessdate=21 May 2018|date=2010-10-31}}</ref>
{{TOC limit|3}}
==Nomenclature== {{See also|Drug nomenclature#Generic names and affixes|l1=Drug nomenclature}}
Generic drug names are constructed using standardized [[affix]]es that distinguish drugs between and within classes and suggest their action.
==Economics== When a pharmaceutical company first markets a drug, it is usually under a patent that, until it expires, the company can use to exclude competitors by suing them for patent infringement.<ref name=GuptaRev2010>{{cite journal|last1=Gupta|first1=H|last2=Kumar|first2=S|last3=Roy|first3=SK|last4=Gaud|first4=RS|title=Patent protection strategies|journal=Journal of Pharmacy & Bioallied Sciences|date=January 2010|volume=2|issue=1|pages=2–7|pmid=21814422|pmc=3146086|doi=10.4103/0975-7406.62694}}</ref> Pharmaceutical companies that develop new drugs generally only invest in drug candidates with strong patent protection as a strategy to recoup their costs to [[drug development|develop the drug]] (including the costs of the drug candidates that fail) and to make a profit.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Frakt|first1=Austin|title=How Patent Law Can Block Even Lifesaving Drugs|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/29/upshot/how-patent-law-can-block-even-lifesaving-drugs.html?_r=0|work=The New York Times|date=28 September 2015}}</ref> The average cost to a brand-name company of discovering, testing, and obtaining regulatory approval for a new drug, with a [[new chemical entity]], was estimated to be as much as $800 million in 2003<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.cptech.org/ip/health/econ/dimasi2003.pdf | title = The price of innovation: new estimates of drug development cost | author = DiMasi J.A. | journal = Journal of Health Economics | volume = 22 | issue = 2 | date = 2003 | pages = 151–185 | doi=10.1016/s0167-6296(02)00126-1|display-authors=etal | pmid=12606142| hdl = 10161/6706 }}</ref> and $2.6 billion in 2014.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://csdd.tufts.edu/news/complete_story/pr_tufts_csdd_2014_cost_study | title = Cost to Develop and Win Marketing Approval for a New Drug Is $2.6 Billion | date = November 18, 2014 | author = Tufts Center for the Study of Drug Development | publisher = [[Tufts University]]}}</ref> Drug companies that bring new products have several [[product line extension]] strategies they use to extend their exclusivity, some of which are seen as gaming the system and referred to by critics as "[[evergreening]]", but at some point there is no patent protection available.<ref name=GuptaRev2010/> For as long as a drug patent lasts, a brand-name company enjoys a period of market exclusivity, or [[monopoly]], in which the company is able to set the price of the drug at a level that maximizes profit. This profit often greatly exceeds the development and production costs of the drug, allowing the company to offset the cost of research and development of other drugs that are not profitable or do not pass clinical trials.<ref name=insider />
Large pharmaceutical companies often spend millions of dollars protecting their patents from generic competition.<ref name="insider" /> Apart from litigation, they may reformulate a drug or license a subsidiary (or another company) to sell generics under the original patent. Generics sold under license from the patent holder are known as [[authorized generics]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gphaonline.org/AM/Template.cfm?Section=Home&TEMPLATE=/CM/HTMLDisplay.cfm&CONTENTID=1932 |title=Authorized Generics |year=2008 |publisher=Generic Pharmaceutical Association (GPhA) |accessdate=2008-06-16 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080529062710/http://www.gphaonline.org/AM/Template.cfm?Section=Home&TEMPLATE=%2FCM%2FHTMLDisplay.cfm&CONTENTID=1932 |archivedate=2008-05-29 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
Generic drugs are usually sold for significantly lower prices than their branded equivalents and at lower [[profit margin]]s.<ref name=Savings>{{cite web|title=Savings From Generic Drugs Purchased at Retail Pharmacies |publisher=[[Food and Drug Administration (United States)|Food and Drug Administration]] |date=April 2004 |url=http://www.fda.gov/cder/consumerinfo/savingsfromgenericdrugs.htm |accessdate=2008-07-11 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080223131005/http://www.fda.gov/cder/consumerinfo/savingsfromgenericdrugs.htm |archivedate=2008-02-23 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> One reason for this is that competition increases among producers when a drug is no longer protected by patents.<ref name=Savings/> Generic companies incur fewer costs in creating generic drugs—only the cost of manufacturing, without the costs of [[drug discovery]] and [[drug development]]—and are therefore able to maintain [[Profit (economics)|profitability]] at a lower price.<ref name=Savings/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clihouston.com/news/the-role-of-reverse-engineering-in-the-development-of-generic-formulations.html|title=The role of reverse engineering in the development of generic formulations|website=www.clihouston.com|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Benson|first1=Mike|title=What it takes to be called 'big pharma' - Market Realist|url=http://marketrealist.com/2015/02/takes-called-big-pharma/|work=Market Realist|date=February 20, 2015}}</ref> The prices are often low enough for users in less-prosperous countries to afford them. For example, Thailand has imported millions of doses of a generic version of the blood-thinning drug [[Plavix]] (used to help prevent heart attacks) from India, the leading manufacturer of generic drugs, at a cost of 3 US cents per dose.<ref>{{cite news |title=Thailand to import generic version of heart drug Plavix from India|date=2007-08-22 |url=https://www.forbes.com/markets/feeds/afx/2007/08/22/afx4043270.html |accessdate=2008-10-13 |work=Forbes}} Forbes.com</ref>
Generic drug companies may also receive the benefit of the previous marketing efforts of the brand-name company, including advertising, presentations by drug representatives, and distribution of free samples. Many drugs introduced by generic manufacturers have already been on the market for a decade or more and may already be well known to patients and providers, although often under their branded name.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
India is a leading country in the world's generic drugs market, exporting US$17.3 billion worth of drugs in the 2017-18 (April-March) year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/with-us-trade-under-a-cloud-china-opens-to-indian-pharma/articleshow/64958667.cms|title=With US trade under a cloud, China opens to Indian pharma}}</ref> India exports generic drugs to the United States and the European Union.
In the United Kingdom, generic drug pricing is controlled by the government's reimbursement rate. The price paid by pharmacists and doctors is determined mainly by the number of license holders, the sales value of the original brand, and the ease of manufacture. A typical price decay graph will show a "scalloped" curve,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pharmaphorum.com/2012/04/04/price-decay-after-loss-brand-exclusivity-patent-expiry-generic-launch/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130131142513/http://www.pharmaphorum.com/2012/04/04/price-decay-after-loss-brand-exclusivity-patent-expiry-generic-launch/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=31 January 2013 |title=Price decay after loss of brand exclusivity (patent expiry) and generic launch |publisher=PharmaPhorum |date=4 Apr 2012 }}</ref> which usually starts at the brand-name price on the day of generic launch and then falls as competition intensifies. After some years, the graph typically flattens out at approximately 20% of the original brand price. In about 20% of cases, the price "bounces": Some license holders withdraw from the market when the selling price dips below their cost of goods, and the price then rises for a while until the license holders re-enter the market with new stock.<ref>{{cite journal | journal = Generics Bulletin | date = 8 Sep 2006 | title = Guessing at prices means losing money}}{{full citation needed|date=August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | journal = Generics Bulletin | date = 16 Feb 2007 | title = Getting to the bottom of 'bouncing' price}}{{full citation needed|date=August 2015}}</ref> The NHS spent about £4.3 billionn on generics medicines in 2016-17.<ref>{{cite news |title=No-deal Brexit 'will force up price of generic drugs' |url=https://www.hsj.co.uk/pharmaceuticals/exclusive-no-deal-brexit-will-force-up-price-of-generic-drugs/7023454.article |accessdate=4 November 2018 |publisher=Health Service Journal |date=26 September 2018}}</ref>
In 2012, 84% of prescriptions in the US were filled with generic drugs,<ref name=GenericDev>{{cite journal|last1=Boehm|first1=Garth|last2=Yao|first2=Lixin|last3=Han|first3=Liang|last4=Zheng|first4=Qiang|title=Development of the generic drug industry in the US after the Hatch-Waxman Act of 1984|journal=Acta Pharmaceutica Sinica B|date=September 2013|volume=3|issue=5|pages=297–311|doi=10.1016/j.apsb.2013.07.004|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2211383513000762}}</ref> and in 2014, the use of generic drugs in the United States led to $254 billion in health care savings.<ref name="gphaonline_2011" />{{rp|2}}
In the mid 2010s the generics industry began transitioning to the end of an era of giant [[patent cliff]]s in the pharmaceutical industry; patented drugs with sales of around $28 billion were set to come off patent in 2018, but in 2019 only about $10 billion in revenue was set to open for competition, and less the next year. Companies in the industry have responded with [[Consolidation (business)|consolidation]] or turning to try to generate new drugs.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Altstedter|first1=Ari|title=Glenmark’s Glenn Saldanha seeks a new holy grail as generic drugs run dry|url=http://www.livemint.com/Companies/RAou6M0VoQyMHz9l2A5zYM/Glenmarks-Glenn-Saldanha-seeks-a-new-holy-grail-as-generic.html|work=Live Mint|date=18 May 2017}}</ref>
==Regulation== Most nations require generic drug manufacturers to prove that their formulations are bioequivalent to their brand-name counterparts.<ref>[http://healthtech.who.int/info_general/documents/TRS937/WHO_TRS_937__annex7_eng.pdf WHO Technical Report Series No. 937: Annex 7] (pdf) WHO Expert Committee on Specifications for Pharmaceutical Preparations, Fortieth Report (WHO Technical Report Series No. 937): Annex 7 - Multisource (generic) pharmaceutical products: guidelines on registration requirements to establish interchangeability, May 2006. Accessed 2008-06-15</ref><ref>[http://www.access.gpo.gov/nara/cfr/waisidx_08/21cfr320_08.html Food and Drug Administration, Department of Health and Human Services: Code of Federal Regulations 320 Title 21, Volume 5, Revised as of April 1, 2008] CFR 320 21/5, Revised as of April 1, 2008. Accessed 2008-06-15</ref><ref>[http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/dhp-mps/prodpharma/applic-demande/guide-ld/bio/index-eng.php Health Canada, Drugs and Health Products, Bioavailability and Bioequivalence] Health Canada, Guidance Documents. Accessed 2008-06-15</ref><ref name="ec.europa.eu">[http://ec.europa.eu/enterprise/pharmaceuticals/eudralex/index.htm EudraLex – The Rules Governing Medicinal Products in the European Union] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528121805/http://ec.europa.eu/enterprise/pharmaceuticals/eudralex/index.htm |date=2010-05-28 }} EudraLex. Accessed 2008-06-15</ref><ref name="ec.europa.eu"/><ref>[http://www.emea.europa.eu/sitemap.htm European Medicines Agency] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091222220346/http://www.emea.europa.eu/sitemap.htm |date=2009-12-22 }} EMEA. Accessed 2008-06-15</ref><ref>[http://www.nihs.go.jp/drug/DrugDiv-E.html Japan, National Institute for Health Sciences, Division of Drugs Guidances] Japan, NIHS, Division of Drugs. Accessed 2008-06-15</ref>
Bioequivalence does not mean generic drugs must be exactly the same as the brand-name product ("pharmaceutical equivalent"). Chemical differences may exist; a different [[Salt (chemistry)|salt]] or [[ester]] may be used, for instance. Different inactive ingredients means that the generic may look different to the originator brand.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Page|first1=A|last2=Etherton-Beer|first2=C|title=Choosing a medication brand: Excipients, food intolerance and prescribing in older people|journal=Maturitas|date=January 2018|volume=107|pages=103–109|doi=10.1016/j.maturitas.2017.11.001|pmid=29169573}}{{open access}}</ref> However, the therapeutic effect of the drug must be the same ("pharmaceutical alternative").{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} Most small molecule drugs are accepted as bioequivalent if their [[pharmacokinetic]] parameters of [[Area under the curve (pharmacokinetics)|area under the curve]] (AUC) and [[Cmax (pharmacology)|maximum concentration]] (C<sub>max</sub>) are within a 90% [[confidence interval]] of 80–125%; most approved generics are well within this limit.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Davit|first=BM |author2=Nwakama PE |author3=Buehler GJ |author4=Conner Dp |author5=Haidar SH |author6=Patel DT |author7=Yang Y |author8=Yu LX |author9=Woodcock J |title=Comparing generic and innovator drugs: a review of 12 years of bioequivalence data from the United States Food and Drug Administration|journal=Annals of Pharmacology|year=2009|volume=43|issue=10 |pages=1583–97|doi=10.1345/aph.1m141|pmid=19776300 |url=https://zenodo.org/record/1236251 |type=Submitted manuscript }}</ref> For more complex products—such as [[inhaler]]s, [[Transdermal patch|patch delivery systems]], [[Liposome|liposomal preparations]], or biosimilar drugs—demonstrating pharmacodynamic or clinical equivalence is more challenging.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Warren|first=JB|title=Generics, chemisimilars and biosimilars: is clinical testing fit for purpose?|journal=Br J Clin Pharmacol|year=2013|volume=75|issue=1|pages=7–14|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2125.2012.04323.x|pmid=22574725|pmc=3555041}}</ref>
===United States=== Enacted in 1984, the [[Drug Price Competition and Patent Term Restoration Act]], informally known as the Hatch-Waxman Act, standardized procedures for recognition of generic drugs. In 2007, the FDA launched the [[Generic Initiative for Value and Efficiency]] (GIVE):<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fda.gov/oc/initiatives/advance/generics.html|title=Generic Initiative for Value and Efficiency (GIVE)|date=October 4, 2007|publisher=FDA|accessdate=2008-06-15}}</ref> an effort to modernize and streamline the generic drug approval process, and to increase the number and variety of generic products available.
Before a company can market a generic drug, it needs to file an [[Abbreviated New Drug Application]] (ANDA) with the Food and Drug Administration, seeking to demonstrate therapeutic equivalence to a previously approved "reference-listed drug" and proving that it can manufacture the drug safely and consistently.<ref name=Mossing/> For an ANDA to be approved, the FDA requires the bioequivalence of a generic drug to be between 80% and 125% of the innovator product.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.fda.gov/Drugs/DevelopmentApprovalProcess/ucm079068.htm |title= Orange Book Annual Preface, Statistical Criteria for Bioequivalence |accessdate= 2009-08-10 |website= Approved Drug Products with Therapeutic Equivalence Evaluations 29th Edition |publisher= U.S. Food and Drug Administration Center for Drug Evaluation and Research |date=2009-06-18 }}</ref> (This range is part of a statistical calculation, and does not mean that generic drugs are allowed to differ from their brand-name counterparts by up to 25 percent.) The FDA evaluated 2,070 studies conducted between 1996 and 2007 that compared the absorption of brand-name and generic drugs into a person’s body. The average difference in absorption between the generic and the brand-name drug was 3.5 percent, comparable to the difference between two batches of a brand-name drug.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.fda.gov/Drugs/ResourcesForYou/Consumers/BuyingUsingMedicineSafely/UnderstandingGenericDrugs/ucm167991.htm | title = Facts about Generic Drugs | publisher = [[Food and Drug Administration]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Davit| year = 2009 | title = Comparing generic and innovator drugs: a review of 12 years of bioequivalence data from the United States Food and Drug Administration | url = https://zenodo.org/record/1236251| journal = Ann Pharmacother | volume = 43 | issue = 10| pages = 1583–97 | doi=10.1345/aph.1m141| pmid = 19776300 |display-authors=etal| type = Submitted manuscript }}</ref> Non-innovator versions of biologic drugs, or biosimilars, require clinical trials for [[immunogenicity]] in addition to tests establishing bioequivalency. These products cannot be entirely identical because of batch-to-batch variability and their biological nature, and they are subject to extra rules.<ref name="biosimilars">{{cite journal|last=Calo-Fernández|first=Bruno|author2=Martínez-Hurtado J L|title=Biosimilars: Company Strategies to Capture Value from the Biologics Market|journal=Pharmaceuticals|date=2012-12-12|volume=5|issue=12|pages=1393–1408|doi=10.3390/ph5121393|url=http://www.mdpi.com/1424-8247/5/12/1393/pdf|accessdate=2012-12-12|pmid=24281342|pmc=3816668}}</ref> [[File:Generic Drug Research (5915) (8493716336).jpg|thumb|Generic Drugs Research]] When an application is approved, the FDA adds the generic drug to its [[Approved Drug Products with Therapeutic Equivalence Evaluations]] list and annotates the list to show equivalence between the reference-listed drug and the generic. The FDA also recognizes drugs that use the same ingredients with different bioavailability, and divides them into therapeutic equivalence groups.<ref name=Mossing>{{cite journal | url = http://plg-group.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Overview-of-the-Hatch-Waxman-act-its-impace-on-Drug-Develo.pdf | pmid = 11758572 | volume=54 | issue = 2 | title=Overview of the Hatch-Waxman Act and its impact on the drug development process | year=1999 | journal=Food Drug Law J | pages=187–94 | author=Mossinghoff GJ}}</ref> For example, as of 2006, [[diltiazem|diltiazem hydrochloride]] had four equivalence groups, all using the same active ingredient, but considered equivalent only within each group.<ref>[http://www.fda.gov/cder/ob/docs/preface/ecpreface.htm#Therapeutic%20Equivalence-Related%20Terms Approved Drug Products with Therapeutic Equivalence Evaluations, Preface.] - an explanation of FDA terms and procedures</ref>
In order to start selling a drug promptly after the patent on innovator drug expires, a generic company has to file its ANDA well before the patent expires. This puts the generic company at risk of being sued for patent infringement, since the act of filing the ANDA is considered "constructive infringement" of the patent.<ref name=Mossing/> In order to incentivize generic companies to take that risk the Hatch-Waxman act granted a 180-day administrative exclusivity period to generic drug manufacturers who are the first to file an ANDA.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/GuidanceComplianceRegulatoryInformation/Guidances/ucm079342.pdf|title=Guidance for Industry: 180-Day Generic Drug Exclusivity Under the Hatch-Waxman Amendments to the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act|date=June 1998|publisher=FDA, Center for Drug Evaluation and Research (CDER)|format=PDF|accessdate=August 24, 2009}}</ref>
When faced with patent litigation from the drug innovator or patent holder, generic companies will often counter-sue, challenging the validity of the patent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fda.gov/cder/ogd/#paragraph|title=Paragraph IV Drug Product Applications: Generic Drug Patent Challenge Notifications|date=2008-06-11|publisher=FDA, Office of Generic Drugs (OGD)|accessdate=2008-06-16}}</ref><ref>[http://newsroom.bms.com/index.php?s=press_releases&item=277] Brisol-Myers Squibb press release on successful defense of Plavix patent {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016185533/http://newsroom.bms.com/index.php?s=press_releases&item=277 |date=October 16, 2007 }}</ref><ref>[https://www.apotex.com/ca/en/about/press/20070321.asp] Apotex press release on successful challenge of Norvasc patent </ref><ref>[http://www.apotex.com/PressReleases/20040426-01.asp] Apotex press release on successful challenge of Paxil patent {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070807213319/http://www.apotex.com/PressReleases/20040426-01.asp |date=August 7, 2007 }}</ref> Like any litigation between private parties, the innovator and generic companies may choose to settle the litigation. Some of these settlement agreements have been struck down by courts when they took the form of [[reverse payment patent settlement]] agreements, in which the generic company basically accepts a payment to drop the litigation, delaying the introduction of the generic product and frustrating the purpose of the Hatch-Waxman Act.<ref>{{cite web |ssrn=2125456 |author = Einer Elhauge & Alex Krueger |title=Solving the Patent Settlement Puzzle |publisher= ''Texas Law Review'' |date = 2012-12-21 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Wyatt |first1=Edward |title=Supreme Court Lets Regulators Sue Over Generic Drug Deals |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/18/business/supreme-court-says-drug-makers-can-be-sued-over-pay-for-delay-deals.html |accessdate=9 May 2015 |work=[[New York Times]] |date=17 June 2013}}</ref>
Innovator companies sometimes try to maintain some of the revenue from their drug after patents expire by allowing another company to sell an [[authorized generic]]; a 2011 FTC report found that consumers benefitted from lower costs when an authorized generic was introduced during the 180 day exclusivity period, as it created competition.<ref>{{cite web|title=#223: Authorized Generic Drug Study|url=https://www.ftc.gov/policy/public-comments/initiative-223|publisher=FTC|date=August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Authorized Generic Drugs: Short-Term Effects and Long-Term ImpactAuthorized Generic Drugs: Short-Term Effects and Long-Term Impact|url=https://www.ftc.gov/sites/default/files/documents/reports/authorized-generic-drugs-short-term-effects-and-long-term-impact-report-federal-trade-commission/authorized-generic-drugs-short-term-effects-and-long-term-impact-report-federal-trade-commission.pdf|publisher=FTC|date=August 2011}}</ref>
Innovator companies may also present arguments to the FDA that the ANDA should not be accepted by filing an [[FDA citizen petition]]. Citizen petitions are part of the basic law governing everything the FDA does—at any time, any "interested person" can request that the FDA "issue, amend, or revoke a regulation or order," or "take or refrain from taking any other form of administrative action."<ref name=Cardozo>{{cite journal|last1=Carrier|first1=Michael A.|last2=Wander|first2=Daryl|title=Citizen Petitions: An Empirical Study|journal=Cardozo Law Review|date=2012|volume=34|pages=249–293|url=http://cardozolawreview.com/content/34-1/Carrier.34.1.pdf}}</ref>
====Acceptance==== A series of scandals around the approval of generic drugs in the late 1980s shook public confidence in generic drugs; there were several instances in which companies obtained bioequivalence data fraudulently, by using the branded drug in their tests instead of their own product, and a congressional investigation found corruption at the FDA, where employees were accepting bribes to approve some generic companies' applications and delaying or denying others.<ref name=GenericDev/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Strickland|first1=Carol|title=Bolar: A Drug Company Under Siege|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/15/nyregion/bolar-a-drug-company-under-siege.html?pagewanted=all|work=The New York Times|date=15 October 1989}}</ref><ref name=NYTexpose1989>{{Cite news|url = https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/10/business/exposing-the-fda.html?pagewanted=all|title = Exposing the F.D.A.|last = Freudenheim|first = Milt|date = 10 September 1989|work = New York Times|accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Andrews|first1=Edmund L.|title=F.D.A. Inquiry on Generic Drugs Focuses on Changes in Ingredients|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/07/31/us/fda-inquiry-on-generic-drugs-focuses-on-changes-in-ingredients.html|work=The New York Times|date=31 July 1989}}</ref>
Some generic drugs are viewed with suspicion by doctors. For example, [[warfarin]] (Coumadin) has a narrow [[Therapeutic index|therapeutic window]] and requires frequent blood tests to make sure patients do not have a subtherapeutic or a toxic level. A study performed in [[Ontario]] showed that replacing Coumadin with generic warfarin was safe,<ref name="Pereira-2005">{{cite journal|vauthors=Pereira JA, Holbrook AM, Dolovich L, Goldsmith C, Thabane L, Douketis JD, Crowther MA, Bates SM, Ginsberg JS |title=Are brand-name and generic warfarin interchangeable? Multiple n-of-1 randomized, crossover trials |journal=Ann Pharmacother |year=2005 |volume=39 |issue=7–8 |pages=1188–93 |pmid=15914517 |url=http://www.theannals.com/cgi/content/full/39/7/1188 |doi=10.1345/aph.1G003 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616070208/http://www.theannals.com/cgi/content/full/39/7/1188 |archivedate=2011-06-16 |df= }}</ref> but many physicians are not comfortable with their patients taking branded generic equivalents.<ref name="Pereira-2005-1">{{cite journal |vauthors=Pereira JA, Holbrook AM, Dolovich L, Goldsmith C, Thabane L, Douketis JD, Crowther M, Bates SM, Ginsberg JS |title=Are brand-name and generic warfarin interchangeable? A survey of Ontario patients and physicians |journal=Can J Clin Pharmacol |year=2005 |volume=12 |issue=3 |pages=e229–39 |pmid=16278495 |url=http://www.cjcp.ca/pdf/CJCP_04-043_e229.pdf |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20071129015145/http://www.cjcp.ca/pdf/CJCP_04-043_e229.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-11-29 |format=PDF |df= }}</ref> In some countries (for example, Australia) where a drug is prescribed under more than one brand name, doctors may choose not to allow pharmacists to substitute a brand different from the one prescribed unless the consumer requests it.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nps.org.au/health_professionals/activities/pharmacy_assistants_kit |title= Generic medicines training kit: safe and appropriate use of generic medicines |accessdate= 2010-01-24 |website= Pharmaceutical Society of Australia Competency Standards for Pharmacists in Australia 2003 |publisher= National Prescribing Service Limited (NPS) |date= 2003-07-09 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091020094049/https://www.nps.org.au/health_professionals/activities/pharmacy_assistants_kit |archivedate= 2009-10-20 |df= }}"Prescribers may disallow [[brand switching]] by ticking the relevant box on the PBS prescription form"</ref>
=====Recalls===== In 2007, [[North Carolina Public Radio]]'s ''The People's Pharmacy'' began reporting on consumers' complaints that generic versions of [[bupropion]] (Wellbutrin) were yielding unexpected effects.<ref name='ConsumerLab.com 2007'>{{cite web | url = https://www.consumerlab.com/reviews/Wellbutrin_vs_Generic_Bupropion/Wellbutrin/ | title = Drug Tests: Wellbutrin vs. Generic Bupropion | accessdate = 2013-04-20 | date = 2012-12-06}}</ref> Subsequently, [[Impax Laboratories]]'s 300 mg extended-release tablets, marketed by [[Teva Pharmaceutical Industries]], were withdrawn from the US market after the FDA determined in 2012 that they were not bioequivalent.<ref name='2012-10-05 Healy'>{{cite news | first = Melissa | last = Healy | title = Generic antidepressant pulled from U.S. shelves after FDA finding | date = 2012-10-05 | url = http://articles.latimes.com/2012/oct/05/news/la-heb-generic-antidepressant-equivilency-20121005 | work = Los Angeles Times | accessdate = 2013-04-20}}</ref><ref name='2012-10-03 FDA'>{{cite web | url = http://www.fda.gov/Drugs/DrugSafety/PostmarketDrugSafetyInformationforPatientsandProviders/ucm322161.htm | title = FDA Update: Budeprion XL 300 mg Not Therapeutically Equivalent to Wellbutrin XL 300 mg | accessdate = 2013-04-20 | date = 2012-10-03 | website = U.S. Food and Drug Administration}}</ref>
=====Litigation===== Two women, each claiming to have suffered severe medical complications from a generic version of [[metoclopramide]], lost their Supreme Court appeal on June 23, 2011. In a 5-4 ruling in [[PLIVA, Inc. v. Mensing]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scotusblog.com/case-files/cases/pliva-inc-v-mensing/|title=PLIVA, Inc. v. Mensing - SCOTUSblog|publisher=|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref><ref>Supreme Court of the United States [https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/10pdf/09-993.pdf 564 PLIVA, Inc. v. Mensing] U. S. ____ (2011)</ref>, the court held that generic companies cannot be held liable for information, or the lack of information, on the originator's label.<ref>Adam Liptak for the New York Times. June 23, 2011 [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/24/business/24bizcourt.html Drug Makers Win Two Supreme Court Decisions]</ref><ref name=Law3602012>Steven Casey for Law360. October 24, 2012 [http://www.law360.com/articles/388965/generic-pharmaceutical-liability-challenges-and-changes Generic Pharmaceutical Liability: Challenges And Changes]</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.cnn.com/2011/HEALTH/06/23/scotus.generic.drugs/index.html?hpt=he_c2 | title = High Court sides with generic drug makers in narrow ruling | date = 2011-06-23 | accessdate = 2013-01-01 | last = Mears | first = B | work = [[CNN]] }}</ref>
===India=== {{main article| Pharmaceutical industry in India}}
The [[Government of India|Indian government]] began encouraging more drug manufacturing by Indian companies in the early 1960s, and with the Patents Act in 1970.<ref>http://www.ircc.iitb.ac.in/IPcourse/patent.html {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100430232700/http://www.ircc.iitb.ac.in/IPcourse/patent.html |date=April 30, 2010 }}</ref> The Patents Act removed composition patents for foods and drugs, and though it kept process patents, these were shortened to a period of five to seven years. The resulting lack of patent protection created a niche in both the Indian and global markets that Indian companies filled by reverse-engineering new processes for manufacturing low-cost drugs.<ref>{{cite journal | journal = Technological Forecasting and Social Change | volume = 79 | issue = 4 | date = 2012 | pages = 607–619 | doi = 10.1016/j.techfore.2011.05.012 | title = The effects of patent-law changes on innovation: The case of India's pharmaceutical industry |author1=George T. Haley |author2=Usha C.V. Haley }}</ref> The code of ethics issued by the [[Medical Council of India]] in 2002 calls for physicians to prescribe drugs by their generic names only.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bhosle|first1=Deepak|last2=Sayyed|first2=Asif|last3=Bhagat|first3=Abhijeet|last4=Shaikh|first4=Huzaif|last5=Sheikh|first5=Alimuddin|last6=Bhopale|first6=Vasundhara|last7=Quazi|first7=Zubair|title=Comparison of Generic and Branded Drugs on Cost Effective and Cost Benefit Analysis|journal=Annals of International Medical and Dental Research|date=20 December 2016|volume=3|issue=1|doi=10.21276/aimdr.2017.3.1.PC1|url=http://aimdrjournal.com/pdf/vol3Issue1/PC_OA_Publication.pdf}}</ref>
=== China === {{main article| Pharmaceutical industry in China}} Generic drug production is a large part of the pharmaceutical industry in China. Western observers have said that China lacks administrative protection for patents.<ref name=unknownworldwatch>{{Citation |title=China's Pharmaceutical Industry Lacks Innovation, Lags Behind |at=worldwatch.org |work=[[China Watch]] |publisher=[[Worldwatch Institute]] |location=Washington, D.C., United States |url=http://www.worldwatch.org/node/3923 |accessdate=Jan 3, 2012 }}</ref> However, entry to the [[World Trade Organization]] has brought a stronger patent system.{{Citation needed|date=May 2016}}
==See also== {{col div|colwidth=30em}} * [[Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement#Criminalising generic medicine]] (ACTA) * [[Bayh–Dole Act]] * [[Biosimilar]]s * [[Chemical patent]]s * [[Evergreening]] * [[Generic brand]] * [[International Nonproprietary Name]] * [[Inverse benefit law]] * [[Me-too compound]] * [[Prescription costs]] * [[Research exemption]] * [[SOPA#Protection against counterfeit drugs]] * [[Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership]] {{colend}}

Professor '''Gio Batta Gori''' is an epidemiologist and fellow with the Health Policy Center in [[Bethesda, Maryland]] which he established in 1997 and where he specializes in risk assessment and scientific research.http://www.manta.com/c/mt7kbjx/health-policy-center He was deputy director of the United States' [[National Cancer Institute]]'s Division of Cancer Cause and Prevention, where he directed the Smoking and Health Program and the Diet and Cancer Program. He organized and directed the Franklin Institute Policy Analysis Center, funded by [[Brown & Williamson]]. He is the [[editor-in-chief]] of the journal [[Regulatory Toxicology and Pharmacology]].[http://www.journals.elsevier.com/regulatory-toxicology-and-pharmacology/editorial-board/ Editorial Board] He has consulted for the [[tobacco industry]], challenging specific scientific claims concerning the risks associated with tobacco use.[http://www.tobacco.neu.edu/litigation/cases/DOJ/20060817KESSLEROPINIONAMENDED.pdf United States of America v. Philip Morris et al.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070721102638/http://www.tobacco.neu.edu/litigation/cases/DOJ/20060817KESSLEROPINIONAMENDED.pdf |date=2007-07-21 }}, Final Opinion of Judge Gladys Kessler, United States District Court for the District of Columbia, p. 162. Accessed October 4, 2007.[http://www.usdoj.gov/civil/cases/tobacco2/20040816%20US%20FACTUAL%20MEMO%20w%20BkMks.pdf United States of America v. Philip Morris et al.], United States Factual Memorandum Pursuant to Order #470, Section V, United States District Court for the District of Columbia, p. 44. Accessed October 4, 2007. He is also known for advocating the regulation and taxation of cigarettes and other tobacco products based on their specific delivery of carcinogens and other hazardous substances, so as to promote risk reduction.Gori, Gio B. ''Virtually Safe Cigarettes: Reviving an Opportunity Once Tragically Rejected.'' IOS Press, 2000.Gori, Gio B. "Less Hazardous Smokes?" ''Regulation'' 25:4 (Winter 2002): 66-72.Gori, Gio B., "Pursuing Less Risky Smokes -- At Last." ''Regulation'' 32:2 (Summer 2009): 3-4. ==National Cancer Institute== Gio Batta Gori has a doctorate in biological sciences and a master's degree in [[public health]]. Between 1968 and 1980, he was a scientist and senior official at the United States' [[National Cancer Institute]] (NCI), where he specialized in [[toxicology]], [[epidemiology]] and [[nutrition]]. He held several positions, including Deputy Director of the Division of Cancer Causes and Prevention; Acting Associate Director, Carcinogenesis Program; Director of the Diet, Nutrition and Cancer Program and Director of the Smoking and Health Program.{{cite web |url=http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/frh21e00 |title=Legacy Tobacco Documents Library: DR. GIO BATTA GORI (frh21e00) |accessdate=2007-07-19 |format= |work=}} ==Gori and the tobacco industry== In 1980 Gori became Vice President of the [[Franklin Institute Policy Analysis Center]] (FIPAC), a consulting firm funded initially by a $400,000 grant from the [[Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation]] (B&W).{{cite web |url=http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/wpw70f00 |title=Legacy Tobacco Documents Library: The Franklin Institute Policy Analysis C... (wpw70f00) |accessdate=2007-07-19 |format= |work=}} Following its initial formation, FIPAC continued to receive hundreds of thousands of dollars in funding annually from B&W.{{cite web |url=http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/krn33f00 |title=Legacy Tobacco Documents Library: -- No Title -- (krn33f00) |accessdate=2007-07-19 |format= |work=}}{{cite web |url=http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/tow70f00 |title=Legacy Tobacco Documents Library: For contribution to Policy Analysis Center program at Franklin Institute (tow70f00)|accessdate=2007-07-22 |format= |work=}}{{cite web |url=http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/rnw70f00 |title=Legacy Tobacco Documents Library: -- No Title -- (rnw70f00) |accessdate=2007-07-19 |format= |work=}} Gori worked on Research & Development projects for B&W Tobacco, such as analysis of the sensory perception of smoke and how to reduce the amount of tobacco in cigarettes. By 1989, Gori was a full-time consultant on [[passive smoking|environmental tobacco smoke]] issues for the [[Tobacco Institute]] in the Institute's ETS/IAQ (Indoor Air Quality) Consultants Project.{{cite web |url=http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/hxh70e00 |title=Legacy Tobacco Documents Library: ETS / IAQ SCIENTIFIC CONSULTANTS (hxh70e00) |accessdate=2007-07-19 |format= |work=}} In May 1993, Gori entered an exclusive consulting arrangement with B&W Tobacco, receiving $200/hour a day to $1,000/day for attending conferences.{{cite web |url=http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/aja53f00 |title=Legacy Tobacco Documents Library: AGREEMENT (aja53f00) |accessdate=2007-07-19 |format= |work=}} In the 118-page book ''Passive Smoke: The EPA's Betrayal of Science and Policy'', Gio Gori and his co-author and fellow industry consultant, [[John Luik]], claim the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) used "junk science" to distort the health effects of secondhand smoke. The book was funded by B&W, which funneled the money through a third party, the Fraser Institute.{{cite web | url = http://www.tobacco.neu.edu/litigation/cases/DOJ/20060817KESSLEROPINIONAMENDED.pdf | title = United States of America v. Philip Morris et al. | publisher = [[United States District Court for the District of Columbia]] | last = Kessler | first = Gladys | accessdate = 2007-07-29 | date = August 17, 2006 | format = PDF | page = 624 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070721102638/http://www.tobacco.neu.edu/litigation/cases/DOJ/20060817KESSLEROPINIONAMENDED.pdf | archivedate = July 21, 2007 | df = }} == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== Following are links to tobacco industry documents from the Legacy Tobacco Documents Library showing work done by Gori for tobacco companies between 1980 and 1999: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Period ! Link ! width="400" | Comment |- | valign="top" | 1980-85 | valign="top" | [http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/pak01c00 Document pak01c00] | valign="top" | Brown and Williamson funded projects
B&W pays Gori $400,000 for the establishment of the Policy Analysis Center.
Other payments follow:
 - 1981: $300,000
 - 1982: $300,000 plus another $300,000
 - 1983: $76,000
 - 1984: $465,000
 - 1985: $253,000 |- | valign="top" | 1981-83 | valign="top" | [http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/lhp33f00 Document lhp33f00] | valign="top" | B&W pays Franklin Institute Operating Fund (Dr. Gori)
 - 1981: $540,000
 - 1982: $1,275,000 |- | valign="top" | 1985-86 | valign="top" | [http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/urj23f00 Document urj23f00]
(page 16) | valign="top" | B&W budget: Dr. Gio Gori
 - 1985: $100,000
 - 1986: $100,000 |- | valign="top" | 1986 | valign="top" | [http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/pup33f00 Document pup33f00]
(page 3) | valign="top" | General Corporate matters: Dr. Gori: $121,111 |- | valign="top" | 1986 | valign="top" | [http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/uue21f00 Document uue21f00] | valign="top" | "Dear Dr. Gori: Enclosed is the consultancy agreement between you and Brown and Williamson ... It has been signed for Brown and Williamson by our President, T. E. Sandefur, Jr." |- | valign="top" | 1986 | valign="top" | [http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/eue21f00 Document eue21f00] | valign="top" | One of many B&W vouchers for Gori lists him as "General Corporate Matters Consultant" Month of September totals about $4K for that month. Credited "as per Gori contract." |- | valign="top" | 1988 | valign="top" | [http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/ksp13f00 Document ksp13f00] | valign="top" | B&W pays Gori $150,000 |- | valign="top" | 1989 | valign="top" | [http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/fif20f00 Document fif20f00] | valign="top" | B&W pays Gori $132,000 Total amount budgeted for Gori in '89: $1,152,000 |- | valign="top" | 1990 | valign="top" | [http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/miq13f00 Document miq13f00] | valign="top" | B&W pays Gori $130,000 |- | valign="top" | 1991 | valign="top" | [http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/yiq13f00 Document yiq13f00] | valign="top" | B&W pays Gori $130,000 |- | valign="top" | 1991 | valign="top" | [http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/hai91f00 Document hai91f00] | valign="top" | Tobacco Institute pays $150,000 to get a white paper written: "{{sic|principle}} author" Gori. Also pays Flamm and Gori $5,000 to write op-ed on the costs of regulation for the Wall Street Journal. Also pays Flamm and Gori $10,000 for another paper. |- | valign="top" | 1992 | valign="top" | [http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/wvp33f00 Document wvp33f00] | valign="top" | Gori bills B&W through B&W's legal firm [[Covington & Burling]] for $10,737 of "consultation services" |- | valign="top" | 1993 | valign="top" | [http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/xjq13f00 Document xjq13f00]
(page 19) | valign="top" | B&W pays Gori $40,000; 1994 budget: another $40,000 for "S&H, Regulatory, GTP" |- | valign="top" | 1993 | valign="top" | [http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/npk93f00 Document npk93f00] | valign="top" | "You will be paid for those services at the agreed rate of $200 per hour for each project assigned to you ... and at the rest of $1000 per day for conference-type work" Letter from Ernest Pepples, VP B&W, to Gio Gori |- | valign="top" | 1999 | valign="top" | [http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/sxy15d00 Document sxy15d00] | valign="top" | "Please find enclosed Lorillard check for $6000" |} ==Bibliography== ===Books=== * Gio Batta Gori, ''Virtually Safe Cigarettes: Reviving an Opportunity Once Tragically Rejected'', IOS Press Inc, January 2000. {{ISBN|1-58603-057-4}} {{ISBN|978-1586030575}} * Gio B. Gori, [[John Luik]], ''Passive Smoke: The EPA's Betrayal of Science and Policy'', The [[Fraser Institute]], 1999. {{ISBN|0-88975-196-X}} ===Articles=== * {{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/01/29/AR2007012901158.html |title=Gio Batta Gori - The Bogus 'Science' of Secondhand Smoke - washingtonpost.com |accessdate=2007-07-18 |work=The Washington Post | date=2007-01-30}} ==Sources== * Text adapted from [http://www.sourcewatch.org/index.php?title=Gio_Batta_Gori] under the GFDL {{DEFAULTSORT:Gori, Gio Batta}} [[Category:Smoking in the United States]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Brown & Williamson]] [[Category:Academic journal editors]] [[Category:American epidemiologists]]

The '''Great Plague of 1738''' was an outbreak of the [[bubonic plague]] between 1738–1740 that affected areas in the modern nations of [[Romania]], [[Hungary]], [[Ukraine]], [[Serbia]], [[Croatia]], and [[Austria]]. Although no exact figure is available, the epidemic likely killed over 50,000 people.
In February 1738 the plague hit the [[Banat]] region, having been spread there by the Imperial Army.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.genealogy.ro/cont/20c.htm|title=history XVIII|publisher=|accessdate=9 September 2016}}</ref>
According to the 1740 Hungarian Diet, the Great Plague claimed 36,000 lives.<ref name="Demographic Changes">[http://mek.oszk.hu/03400/03407/html/280.html Demographic Changes<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Southeastern Transylvania may have been the hardest area hit. Over the following eight years, the plague killed a sixth of the population of [[Timişoara]]. Timişoara's Monument of the Holy Trinity in Piaţa Unirii is dedicated to the plague's victims. The plague would return to hit the city again in 1762–1763.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thekonst.net/en/propaganda/226|title=thekonst.net :: propaganda. weekly notes by konst :: the cradle of Romanian Revol..|publisher=|accessdate=9 September 2016}}</ref>
Other cities in the region were also stricken. Between October 1737 and April 1738, 111 deaths were reported in [[Zărneşti]], and 70 in [[Codlea]].<ref name="Demographic Changes"/> More than 10% of the population of [[Cluj-Napoca]] was reported to have been killed by the pandemic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clujonline.com/history/history.htm|title=CLUJ-NAPOCA, The Treasure City of Transylvania, Romania - History|publisher=|accessdate=9 September 2016}}</ref>
The disease's spread extended to the [[Adriatic]]. It made its way to the island of [[Brač]] in modern-day Croatia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.croatians.com/sumartin_island_of_brac.htm|title=www.croatians.com|publisher=|accessdate=9 September 2016}}</ref>
By the summer, the [[Serbia]]n region of Grad [[Zrenjanin]] was also affected.<ref>[http://www.zrenjanin.org.rs/ogradu/ogradu/eistorija.htm History<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==See also== *[[Black Death]] *[[Bubonic plague]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} [[File:Sarpa salpa .jpg|thumb|300px|right|{{center|Ingesting the dreamfish ''[[Sarpa salpa]]'' can result in hallucinations that last for several days.}}]] Several species of fish are claimed to produce hallucinogenic effects when consumed. For example, ''[[Sarpa salpa]]'', a species of [[sea bream]], is commonly claimed to be hallucinogenic.[http://www.mahalo.com/sarpa-salpa/ Sarpa Salpa] ''[[Mahalo]]''{{unreliable source?|date=September 2017}} These widely distributed [[coastal fish]] are normally found in the Mediterranean and around Spain, and along the west and south coasts of Africa. Occasionally they are found in British waters.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/earth/earthnews/5318202/Fish-that-triggers-hallucinations-found-off-British-coast.html Fish that triggers hallucinations found off British coast] ''The Telegraph'', 13 May 2009.{{Failed verification|date=May 2017}} They may induce hallucinogenic effects that are purportedly [[LSD]]-like if eaten.[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/may/13/hallucination-fish-cornwall 'Hallucination' fish netted in Channel] ''The Guardian'', 13 May 2009. In 2006, two men who apparently ate the fish experienced hallucinations lasting for several days. {{cite journal | author = de Haro, L. |author2=Pommier, P. | title = Hallucinatory fish poisoning (ichthyoallyeinotoxism): two case reports from the Western Mediterranean and literature review | journal = Clinical Toxicology | year = 2006 | volume = 44 | issue = 2 | pages = 185–8 | pmid = 16615678 | doi = 10.1080/15563650500514590}} {{cite news |url = http://www.practicalfishkeeping.co.uk/content.php?sid=888 |title = Men hallucinate after eating fish |first = Matt |last = Clarke |work = Practical Fishkeeping |date = 19 April 2006 |accessdate = 31 March 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110605090450/http://www.practicalfishkeeping.co.uk/content.php?sid=888 |archivedate = 5 June 2011 |df = dmy-all }} The likelihood of hallucinations depends on the season.de Haro L, Jouglard DE, Thomas MJ and David JM (1994) "Intoxications de type ciguatera after eating the Sparidae in Mediterranean". In Boudoresque, CF, Meinsez A and Gravez V. (Eds) [https://books.google.com/books/about/First_International_Workshop_on_Caulerpa.html?id=XsYTAAAACAAJ&redir_esc=y ''First International Workshop on Caulerpa taxifolia''] GIS Posidonie Publ., France, pp. 271–274. {{ISBN|9782905540195}}.Bellassoued K, Hamza A, Abdelmouleh A, Pelt JV and El Feki A (2011) [https://world-food.net/download/journals/2011-issue_1/57.pdf "Antioxidant response in the salema ''Sarpa salpa'': Interseasonal correlations with the diet"] ''J. Food. Agric. Environ.'', '''9''' (1): 730–733. ''Sarpa salpa'' is known as "the fish that makes dreams" in [[Arabic]]. Other species claimed to be capable of producing hallucinations include several species of [[sea chub]] from the genus ''[[Kyphosinae|Kyphosus]]''. It is unclear whether the toxins are produced by the fish themselves or by marine algae in their diet. Other hallucinogenic fish are ''[[Siganus]] spinus'', called "the fish that inebriates" in [[Reunion Island]], and ''[[Mulloidichthys]] flavolineatus'' (formerly ''Mulloidichthys samoensis''), called "the chief of ghosts" in Hawaii.{{cite book|last=Thomas, Craig, M.D. and|first=Susan Scott|title=All Stings Considered: First Aid and Medical Treatment of Hawai'i's Marine Injuries|date=June 1, 1997|publisher=University of Hawai'i Press|location=Hawaii|isbn=9780824819002|pages=120|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=okQ78Yt-73IC&pg=PA120&lpg=PA120&dq=samoensis}} ==Cause of hallucinations== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | image1 = Caulerpa prolifera.JPG | width1 = 160 | alt1 = | caption1 = Some fish may become hallucinogenic after grazing on ''[[Caulerpa prolifera]]'', a species of [[green alga]] that forms dense beds on shallow sandy areas. | image2 = Posidonia 2 Alberto Romeo.jpg | width2 = 236 | alt2 = | caption2 = Also implicated is ''[[Posidonia oceanica]]'', a [[seagrass]] that lives in meadows along the Mediterranean coast. }} The active agent(s) that cause hallucinations in humans, and the origin of these agents, are not clear. Some authors think they could come from toxins associated with [[macroalgae]] that accumulate in the flesh of the fish. Toxins from the [[green algae]] ''[[Caulerpa prolifera]]'' in the Mediterranean Sea appear to be implicated, as is the [[seagrass]] ''[[Posidonia oceanica]]''.Bellassoued K, A Hamza, A Abdelmouleh, FA Makni, JV Pelt and A Elfeki (2012) [http://wflpublisher.net/download/journal-content/contents-april-2012issue%202.pdf "Toxicity assessment of dreamfish ''Sarpa salpa'' from the Gulf of Gabes (Tunisia, Eastern Mediterranean Sea)"] ''Journal of Food, Agriculture and Environment'', '''10''' (2): 1308–1313. When [[herbivore]]s eat seagrass leaves they ingest algal [[epiphyte]]s and toxic [[dinoflagellate]]s that live on the seagrass leaves.Kitting CL, Fry B and Morgan MD (1984) [https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00379006#page-1 "Detection of inconspicuous epiphytic algae supporting food webs in seagrass meadows"] ''Oecologia'', '''62''' :145–149. The German anthropologist [[Christian Rätsch]] thinks that dreamfish might contain the hallucinogen [[Dimethyltryptamine|DMT]].[[Clifford A. Pickover|Pickover, Clifford A]] (2005) [ ''Sex, Drugs, Einstein, and Elves''] Chapter 1, page 9, Smart Publications. {{ISBN|9781890572174}}. {{quote|"A few reporters have eaten the dream fish and described their strange effects. The most famous user is Joe Roberts, a photographer for the ''National Geographic'' magazine. He broiled the dream fish in 1960. After eating the delicacy, he experienced intense hallucinations with a science-fiction theme that included futuristic vehicles, images of space exploration, and monuments marking humanity's first trips into space."[[Clifford A. Retrieved 23 October 2013.{{FishBase species| genus=Epinephelus | species=corallicola | year=2013 | month=October }} |} ==Ichthyoallyeinotoxism== {{main|Ichthyoallyeinotoxism}} [[Ichthyoallyeinotoxism]], or hallucinogenic fish inebriation, is a clinical syndrome that refers to a hallucinogenic [[inebriation]] of a distressing nature that can arise from consuming hallucinogenic fish. It is characterised by "psychologic disturbances of hallucination and depression. Gastrointestinal disturbance may occur".[http://www.spc.int/DigitalLibrary/Doc/FAME/Meetings/Meetings_on_Ciguatera/Seminar_Ichthyosarcotoxism_68/Report.pdf Report of the Seminar on Ichthyosarcotoxism] Papeete 1968, ''South Pacific Commission''. "Ichthyoallyeinotoxism is a kind of ichthysarcotoxism (fish flesh poisoning) responsible of an unusual clinical feature: it is the unique case of central nervous system [[wikt:ichthyotoxicity|ichthyotoxicity]]. The most frequent signs are dizziness, loss of co-ordination and hallucinations."de Haro, L., Prost, N., Arditti, J., David, J. M., & Jouglard, J. (1998) [http://yadda.icm.edu.pl/yadda/element/bwmeta1.element.elsevier-8bca58ea-fd50-38a1-b9b4-6f1dc88725e9 "Ichthyoallyeinotoxism: a rare pathology"] ''Toxicon'', '''36''' (12): 1738–1739.
Ichthyoallyeinotoxism may result from eating the flesh or the head of the fish where the poison is reputedly concentrated. This biotoxication is sporadic and unpredictable in its occurrence. The poison affects primarily the central nervous system. The symptoms may develop within a few minutes to 2 hours and persist for 24 hours or longer. Symptoms are dizziness, loss of equilibrium, lack of motor coordination, hallucinations and mental depression. A common complaint of the victim is that "someone is sitting on my chest", or there is a sensation of a tight construction around the chest. The conviction that he is going to die, or some other frightening phantasy, is a characteristic part of the clinical picture. Other complaints consist of itching, burning of the throat, muscular weakness and abdominal distress. No fatalities have been reported, and in comparison with other forms of ichthyosarcotoxism, hallucinogenic fish poisoning is relatively mild... Ordinary cooking procedures do not destroy the poison.R Bagnis R, F Berglund, PS Elias, GJ van Esch, BW Halstead and K Kojima (1970) [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2427509/pdf/bullwho00212-0080.pdf "Problems of Toxicants in Marine Food Products: 1. Marine biotoxins"] ''Bulletin of the World Health Organization'', '''42''': 69–88.
==Psychedelic fish== Hallucinogenic fish can be contrasted with [[Psychedelic art|psychedelic]] fish. Psychedelic fish do not produce hallucinations if eaten, but look as if they were the product of a [[psychedelic drug|psychedelic]] hallucination.[http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2009/02/090226-psychedelic-fish-picture-ap.html "Psychedelic" fish picture: New Species Bounces on Reef] ''National Geographic'', 25 February 2009.[http://www.practicalfishkeeping.co.uk/content.php?sid=3890 The Psychedelic mandarin] ''Practical fishkeeping'', 4 May 2011.Department of Defense (2000) [https://books.google.com/books?id=TGvVsq42Lt8C&pg=PT13 ''Coral Reef Protection Implementation Plan''] Diane Publishing. {{ISBN|9781428911260}}. File:Psychedelic frogfish 08Am7A1b.jpg|{{center|[[Psychedelic frogfish]]{{FishBase species| genus=Histiophryne | species=psychedelica | year=2013 | month=October }}}} File:Palma Aquarium-Pez mandarín.jpg|{{center|[[Psychedelic mandarin]]{{FishBase species| genus=Synchiropus | species=picturatus | year=2013 | month=October }}}} File:Synchiropus splendidus 2 Luc Viatour cropped.png|{{center|[[Synchiropus splendidus]]{{FishBase species| genus=Synchiropus | species=splendidus | year=2013 | month=October }}}} {{clear}} ==See also== * [[5-Bromo-DMT]] * [[Entheogen]] * [[Hallucinogenic plant]] * [[Serotonergic psychedelic]] * [[Venomous fish]] ==References== {{reflist|32em}} ==External links== * [http://www.news.com.au/technology/science/dolphins-getting-high-on-puffer-fish-zoologist-rob-pilley-says/story-fn5fsgyc-1226791707165 Dolphins 'getting high' on puffer fish, zoologist Rob Pilley says] ''news.com.au'', 30 December 2013. {{diversity of fish|state=expanded}} [[Category:Biological sources of psychoactive drugs]] [[Category:Poisonous fish]] [[Category:Toxic effect of noxious substances eaten as food]] [[Category:Hallucinations]]
